revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=January 2009}} {{Japanese name|Akaza}} {{nihongo|'''Akaza Naoyasu'''|赤座 直保||extra=? – 1606}} was a Japanese ''[[daimyō]]'' of the [[Azuchi–Momoyama period]], who served [[Toyotomi Hideyoshi]]. He was also known as {{nihongo|'''Kyūbei'''|久兵衛}} and {{nihongo|'''Yoshiie'''|吉家}}, and held the title of {{nihongo|[[Kokushi (officials)|Bingo-no-kami]]|備後守}}. His father, {{nihongo|Akaza Naonori|赤座 直則}}, was a retainer of [[Oda Nobunaga]]. Naonori was killed in action when [[Akechi Mitsuhide]] attacked and killed Nobunaga at [[Honnō-ji]]. ([[Incident at Honnōji]])
Naoyasu then served Toyotomi Hideyoshi. He took part in capturing [[Iwatsuki Castle]] and [[Oshi Castle]] at [[Musashi Province]] in the [[Siege of Odawara (1590)|siege of Odawara]], and was given 20,000 ''[[koku]]''. After that, based in Imajo, [[Echizen Province]], he supported [[Kobayakawa Hideaki]] and [[Horio Yoshiharu]].
In 1600 at the [[Battle of Sekigahara]], he was under [[Ōtani Yoshitsugu]], who led part of [[Ishida Mitsunari]]'s force. However, taking advantage of Kobayakawa Hideaki's betrayal, he switched sides with [[Wakisaka Yasuharu]], [[Kutsuki Mototsuna]] and [[Ogawa Suketada]]. Together, they defeated Yoshitsugu's force. After the battle, [[Tokugawa Ieyasu]] did not give Naoyasu credit and seized his domain. Because of that, Naoyasu became a retainer of [[Maeda Toshinaga]], and was given a stipend of 7,000 koku.
In 1606, looking over flooded Daimon River, in [[Etchū Province]], he fell off a horse and died by drowning. Naoyasu was survived by his son, {{nihongo|Akaza Takaharu|赤座孝治}}. Takaharu changed his family name to {{nihongo|Nagahara|永原}}, and became a retainer of the [[Maeda clan]] of [[Kaga Domain|Kaga]]. The family remained retainers of the Maeda until the [[Meiji Restoration]].
==References== *{{ja icon}} [[:ja:赤座直保|Japanese Wiki article on Naoyasu]] (retrieved 14 Sept.)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Akaza, Naoyasu}} [[Category:1606 deaths]] [[Category:Daimyo]] [[Category:Samurai]] [[Category:Deaths by drowning]] [[Category:Deaths by horse-riding accident]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in Japan]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:16th-century Japanese people]] [[Category:17th-century Japanese people]] {{daimyo-stub}} {{samurai-stub}}

'''Al-Hasan ibn al-Fairuzan''' ([[Floruit|fl.]] 10th century) was a [[Daylamite]] prince from the [[Firuzanids|Firuzanid family]].
== Biography == [[File:Caspian coast of Iran during the Iranian intermezzo.png|thumb|right|300px|Map of northern Iran]] Al-Hasan was the son of [[Fairuzan]], a Daylamite soldier, who along with his brother [[Kaki ibn Nu'man|Kaki]] served the [[Alid dynasties of northern Iran]].<ref name="EI2-164">Nazim (1987), p. 164</ref> In 902, both of them were killed during a [[Samanid]] invasion of Tabaristan. Kaki had a son named [[Makan ibn Kaki]], who together with al-Hasan served the Alids. Makan had established family ties through marriage with the Alids, as [[Ja'far ibn al-Nasir|Ja'far]], the son of [[imam]] [[Hasan ibn Ali al-Utrush]] (r. 914–917), was his son-in-law.<ref name="EI2-164"/> The latter was engaged in a complex struggle against al-Utrush's designated successor [[Abu Muhammad Hasan ibn Qasim]], known as the ''[[Da'i]] ila'l-Haqq'' (r. 917–928), and it was not until 923 that Ja'far and his brother [[Ahmad ibn al-Nasir|Ahmad]] succeeded in ousting the ''Da'i'' and forcing him to exile.<ref>Madelung (1975), pp. 210–211</ref> When Ja'far died in 924, he left the throne to Ahmad's son [[Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn al-Nasir|Abu Ali Muhammad]], but al-Hasan and Makan deposed Muhammad and installed al-Hasan's half-brother [[Ismail ibn Ja'far ibn al-Nasir|Ismail]], a son of Ja'far and the mother of al-Hasan, in his place.<ref name="EI2-164"/><ref name="Iran211">Madelung (1975), p. 211</ref> Muhammad, however, managed to escape from his captors and with the aid of the [[Gilaks|Gilaki]] military chief [[Asfar ibn Shiruya]], who had seized control of [[Gurgan]], defeated the two brothers and retook his throne.<ref name="EI2-164"/><ref name="Iran211"/>
In 930, Makan managed to recover Tabaristan, and appointed al-Hasan as the governor of the region. Makan also made Abu Muhammad Hasan ibn Qasim the imam of the Alids. A fake rumor later spread about the death of Makan,<ref name="Espandiyar">Ibn Isfandiyar (1905), pp. 204-270</ref> which made al-Hasan, who wanted to install his half-brother Ismail as the imam, rise into rebellion. However, the rebellion failed after Ismail was poisoned at the instigation of Abu Ja'far Husayn's mother.<ref name="Iran212">Madelung (1975), p. 212</ref> Al-Hasan was shortly driven out from [[Amol]] by two officers of Makan named Abu Ali and Abu Musa. Al-Hasan then fled to [[Daylam]].<ref name="Espandiyar"/> Makan was himself shortly driven out from Tabaristan by the [[Ziyarid]] ruler [[Mardavij]].<ref name="EI2-164"/><ref name="Iran212"/>
In 935, Mardavij was assassinated and succeeded by his brother [[Vushmgir]]. Makan was appointed by his new overlords, the Samanids, as the governor of Gurgan. Vushmgir himself shortly recognized Samanid suzerainty, and Al-Hasan was appointed as the governor of [[Sari, Iran|Sari]]. Relations between Makan and Vushmgir improved to the point where the former felt secure enough to drop his dependence on the Samanids. As a result, in 939 a Samanid army under [[Abu 'Ali Chaghani]] attacked him at Gurgan. Following a seven-month siege of his capital, Makan was forced to flee to Rayy. The Samanid army pursued him, and in a battle fought on 25 December 940 at [[Battle of Iskhabad|Iskhabad]] near Rayy, the Samanid forces were victorious. Makan himself was killed by an arrow, and then beheaded by the victors, who sent his head to the Samanid court in [[Bukhara]].<ref name="Iran213">Madelung (1975), p. 213</ref><ref>Nazim (1987), p. 165</ref> [[File:Iran circa 1000AD.png|thumb|right|300px|Persia in the mid-10th century]] Vushmgir, after the disastrous defeat, fled back to Tabaristan, but al-Hasan, who blamed Vushmgir for the death of his cousin, shortly rebelled against him. Vushmgir managed to defeat him, but al-Hasan convinced Abu 'Ali Chaghani to invade Tabaristan. Vushmgir was forced to recognize Samanid authority again.
When Abu 'Ali Chaghani left for Samanid [[Greater Khorasan|Khurasan]], Vushmgir retook control of Ray. He then lost it for good in 943, to the [[Buyid]] ruler [[Rukn al-Dawla|Hasan]]. Returning to Tabaristan, he was defeated there by al-Hasan, who had previously occupied Gurgan. Vushmgir fled to the court of the [[Bavandid]] [[Shahriyar II]], and then to the court of the Samanid [[Nuh I of Samanid|Nuh I]]. Al-Hasan meanwhile allied with Hasan, but when Abu 'Ali Chaghani took Ray from the Buyids in 945, he recognized Samanid authority. Still, in 945 Vushmgir captured Gurgan with Samanid support, but did not manage to retain his rule there. It was only in 947 when he was able to take Gurgan and Tabaristan from al-Hasan with the help of a large Samanid army.
In 948, the Buyid ruler [[Rukn al-Dawla|Hasan]] (who since the Buyids' entrance into [[Baghdad]] in 945 had used the title ''Rukn al-Dawla'') invaded Tabaristan and Gurgan and took them from Vushmgir. While al-Hasan supported the Buyids, Vushmgir relied on his Samanid allies. Al-Hasan thereafter disappears from the history chronicles, and is first mentioned again in 967 after the death of Vushmgir, as the ruler of [[Semnan (city)|Simnan]], and aiding Vushmgir's son [[Qabus]] in his claims for the Ziyarid throne.
The fate of al-Hasan after this is unknown, he had two sons named [[Firuzan ibn al-Hasan]] and [[Nasr ibn al-Hasan]]. He also had a daughter who married Rukn al-Dawla, and bore him three sons named [[Fakhr al-Dawla|Abu'l-Hasan Ali]], [[Mu'ayyad al-Dawla|Buya ibn Hasan]], and [[Adud al-Dawla|Fanna Khusraw]].
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== Sources == * {{cite book | title = The Cambridge History of Iran, Volume 4: From the Arab Invasion to the Saljuqs | year = 1975 | publisher = Cambridge University Press | location = Cambridge | editor-last = Frye | editor-first = R.N. | last = Madelung | first = W. | authorlink = Wilferd Madelung | chapter = The Minor Dynasties of Northern Iran | pages = 198–249 | isbn = 978-0-521-20093-6 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=hvx9jq_2L3EC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA198#v=onepage&q&f=false}} * {{cite encyclopedia | article=Mākān b. Kākī | first = M. | last = Nazim | encyclopedia = E.J. Brill's first encyclopaedia of Islam, 1913–1936, Volume V: L–Moriscos | editor-first = Martijn Theodoor | editor-last = Houtsma | publisher = BRILL | location = Leiden | year = 1987 | isbn = 90-04-08265-4 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iJQ3AAAAIAAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA164#v=onepage&q&f=false | pages = 164–165 }} * {{cite book | title = The Monumental Inscriptions from Early Islamic Iran and Transoxiana | year = 1992 | publisher = BRILL | location = | editor-last = | editor-first = | last = Blair | first = Sheila | authorlink = | chapter = | pages = 1–307 | isbn = 9789004093676 | url = https://books.google.dk/books?id=4U0fCVfM8q8C&dq=Ibn+Makan&hl=da&source=gbs_navlinks_s=false}} * {{cite book | title = An Abridged Translation of the History of Tabaristan | year = 1905 | publisher = BRILL | location = University of Michigan | editor-last = | editor-first = | last = Ibn | first = Isfandiyar | authorlink = | chapter = | pages = 1–356 | isbn = 9789004093676 | url = https://books.google.dk/books?ei=ShcaU8KrI8rf4QT_s4CoAQ&hl=da&id=HhNgAAAAMAAJ&dq=Hasan+ibn+Firuzan&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%27}}

revision.text:
'''Ambelopoulia''' is a controversial dish of grilled, fried, pickled or boiled songbirds which is a traditional dish<ref name=a>{{cite web|title=Αμπελοπούλια ξιδάτα|url=http://foodmuseum.cs.ucy.ac.cy/web/guest/parsintages/civitem/2455#_bs_civitems_tabcyprus.rec.tab1|website=foodmuseum.cs.ucy.ac.cy|publisher=Cyprus Food Virtual Museum|accessdate=26 November 2015|language=Greek}}</ref> enjoyed by native Cypriots and served in some [[Cypriot cuisine|Cypriot]] restaurants. It is illegal in [[Cyprus]] as it involves [[bird trapping|trapping wild birds]] such as [[blackcap]]s and [[European robin]]s. Trapping kills birds indiscriminately, thus internationally protected species of migratory birds are killed as well. Enforcement of the ban has been lax, so many restaurants serve the dish without consequence. As a result almost 2,418,000 birds across the whole of Cyprus are estimated to have been killed during 2010.<ref name=blc>{{cite web |url=http://www.birdlifecyprus.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=38&Itemid=56&lang=en| author=BirdLifeCyprus| title=Frontline News on Illegal Bird Trapping in Cyprus - Spring 2010 |date=August 5, 2010| accessdate=August 12, 2010}}</ref> According to a [[BirdLife Cyprus]] report released in 2014, over 1.5 million migrating songbirds are killed annually, and the number is increasing each year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenprophet.com/2013/12/cyprus-kills-ambelopoulia-birds/|title=Cyprus kills 1.5 million migrating songbirds to eat in fetish dish|publisher=}}</ref> In 2015 it is estimated that over 2 million birds were killed including over 800,000 on the [[Akrotiri and Dhekelia|British Territories]] and a further 800,000 on the British Territories in the autumn of 2016.<ref name=birdguides>{{cite web|title=RSPB Mass killing continues on British military base in Cyprus|url=http://www.birdguides.com/iris/pictures.asp?f=433834|website=BirdGuides|accessdate=16 March 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161120211328/http://www.birdguides.com/iris/pictures.asp?f=433834|archivedate=20 November 2016|df=}}</ref><ref name=rspb>{{cite web|title=Hundreds of thousands of birds still being illegally killed on British military base in Cyprus but annual increase halted|url=http://www.rspb.org.uk/news/416276-hundreds-of-thousands-of-birds-still-being-illegally-killed-on-british-military-base-in-cyprus-but-annual-increase-halted-|website=RSPB|accessdate=16 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="bbc355">{{cite magazine|title=No End To Cyprus Bird Toll|journal=BBC Wildlife|date=2017|volume=35|issue=5|page=54}}</ref>
The birds are trapped in either of two ways. Black, fine-mesh nylon fishing nets, which are difficult to see, are strung between planted [[acacia]] trees. Electronic bird calls lure the birds to entangle their wings and legs, or alternatively gravel is brought in by truck and is thrown at the base of the trees to scare the birds into the nets.<ref name=rspb/> Others are trapped using glue sticks made from the berries of a local tree or [[birdlime]]. The glue sticks are placed on the branches of trees, and any birds that perch on them are stuck until the trapper returns to kill them (usually with a tooth pick to the throat). Often the legs of the birds are so stuck to the glue sticks that they need to be pulled off. Protests against the removal of acacia scrub has resulted in 36 ha remaining in 2016, compared with 56 ha in 2014.<ref name="bbc355"/>
The trappers defend their activity by citing the practice as traditional Cypriot food gathering and claiming that this has been an important source of protein for the natives for many thousands of years, even though the practice has been illegal since 1974. [[BirdLife]] Cyprus has identified restaurants as the main culprits as they provide the financial incentives.<ref name=blc/> The enthusiasm Cypriots and many other visitors to the island have for this delicacy despite its illegality has resulted in the development of a very profitable industry. Poaching for ambelopoulia has been on the rise in recent years, involving by 2011 a "mafia-like operation" that include poachers, dealers, exporters, and restaurant operators that participate in the illegal business estimated to be worth about 5 million euro at that time.<ref>{{cite journal| url=http://www.cyprus-mail.com/crime/poachers-mafia-operation/20110611| author=Nathan Morley| title=Poachers ‘mafia-like’ operation| journal=[[Cyprus Mail]]| date=June 11, 2011| accessdate=July 7, 2011| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715180525/http://www.cyprus-mail.com/crime/poachers-mafia-operation/20110611| archivedate=July 15, 2011| df=}}</ref> The birds reportedly sell for five euros each and it is estimated by Cypriot authorities to have earned criminals on the island 15 million euro in 2015.<ref name=birdguides/>
Since the entrails of the birds are not removed, as it is not cost effective to do so, the consumer is encouraged to swallow the bird whole.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.proact-campaigns.net/responsecyprus/id13.html|title=Proact-campaigns.net|publisher=|access-date=2007-02-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928093844/http://www.proact-campaigns.net/responsecyprus/id13.html|archive-date=2007-09-28|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Unsuspecting diners may be served much cheaper farmed birds such as immature quails by some restaurants.
==See also== *[[Ortolan bunting]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2010/07/26/100726fa_fact_franzen Jonathan Franzen, ''Emptying the Skies'', [[The New Yorker]], July 26, 2010]

{{for|the English footballer|Arthur Blackburn (footballer)}} {{EngvarB|date=April 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox military person |name= Arthur Seaforth Blackburn |image= Arthur Blackburn J03069A.JPG |image_size= |alt= |caption= Captain A. S. Blackburn {{circa}} 1919 |nickname= |birth_date= {{birth date|1892|11|25|df=yes}} |birth_place= [[Woodville, South Australia]] |death_date= {{death date and age|1960|11|24|1892|11|25|df=yes}} |death_place= [[Crafers, South Australia]] |placeofburial= |allegiance= Australia |branch= [[Australian Army]] |serviceyears= 1914–1917
1924–1946 |rank= [[Brigadier]] |unit= |commands= Black Force (1942)
[[2/3rd Machine Gun Battalion (Australia)|2/3rd Machine Gun Battalion]] (1940–42)
[[18th Light Horse Regiment|18th Light Horse (Machine Gun) Regiment]] (1939–40) |battles= First World War * [[Gallipoli Campaign]] ** [[Landing at Anzac Cove]] * [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] ** [[Battle of the Somme]] ** [[Battle of Pozières]] Second World War * [[North African Campaign]] * [[Syria-Lebanon Campaign]] * [[Dutch East Indies campaign]] |awards= [[Victoria Cross]]
[[Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George]]
[[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]]
[[Efficiency Decoration]] |relations= [[Richard Blackburn|Sir Richard Blackburn]] (son) |laterwork= Member for [[Electoral district of Sturt (South Australia)|Sturt]] (1918–21)
Commissioner in the [[Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration]] (1947–55) }} [[Brigadier]] '''Arthur Seaforth Blackburn''', {{postnominals|country=AUS|size=100%|sep=,|VC|CMG|CBE|ED}} (25 November 1892 – 24 November 1960) was a South Australian soldier, lawyer, politician, and an [[List of Australian Victoria Cross recipients|Australian recipient]] of the [[Victoria Cross]], the highest award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to British and [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] forces. ==Early life== Blackburn was born on 25 November 1892 at [[Woodville, South Australia|Woodville]], South Australia. His parents were the cleric and entomologist [[Thomas Blackburn (entomologist)|Thomas Blackburn]] and his wife Margaret Harriette Stewart, ''née'' Browne. He was educated at [[Pulteney Grammar School]], [[St Peter's College, Adelaide|the Collegiate School of St Peter]] and the [[University of Adelaide]] (LL.B., 1913). ==First World War== ===Gallipoli=== In 1914, Private Blackburn, a 21-year-old lawyer from [[Adelaide]], was among the first to enlist in the [[10th Battalion (Australia)|"Fighting 10th" Battalion]], and as a battalion scout he was among the first to [[Landing at Anzac Cove|land at Anzac Cove]] on 25 April 1915.{{cite web|url=http://discoveringanzacs.naa.gov.au/browse/person/90949 |title=First World War Service Record – Arthur Seaforth Blackburn |publisher=[[National Archives of Australia]] |accessdate=10 October 2014}} Australia's official First World War historian, [[Charles Bean]], noted that Blackburn, with Lance Corporal Robin, probably made it further inland than any other Australian soldiers "whose movements are known". Blackburn was commissioned as a [[second lieutenant]] at Gallipoli in August 1915, and served there for almost the entire campaign. ===Western Front=== On 23 July 1916, at [[Battle of Pozières|Pozières]], France, the 23-year-old second lieutenant led an attack for which he was awarded the [[Victoria Cross]]. Blackburn was directed with 50 men to drive the enemy from a strong point. By great determination he captured 250 yards of trench, after personally leading four separate parties of bombers against it, many of whom became casualties. Then after crawling forward with a sergeant to reconnoitre, he returned, attacked again, and seized another 120 yards of trench to establish communication with the battalion on his left.{{London Gazette|issue=29740|supp=y|page=8870|date=8 September 1916}} Blackburn returned to Australia on 22 March 1917, married Rose Ada Kelly, and was discharged on medical grounds soon after. ==Between the wars== Blackburn returned to legal practice and took an active part in the pro-conscription campaigns. During 1918–21 he was [[National Party (South Australia)|National Party]] member for [[Electoral district of Sturt (South Australia)|Sturt]] in the [[South Australian House of Assembly]]; he did not seek re-election in 1921. Blackburn was a founding member of the [[Returned and Services League|Returned Sailors', Soldiers' and Airmen's Imperial League]] in South Australia, where he served as president of the State branch from 1917–21. He joined the militia in 1924. In 1933–47 Blackburn was city coroner, in which office he encountered and ignored criticism for refusing to offer public explanation for any decision not to hold an inquest. ==Second World War== In 1939, Blackburn was promoted to [[lieutenant colonel]] and took command of a motorised cavalry regiment, the [[18th Light Horse Regiment|18th Light Horse (Machine Gun) Regiment]].{{cite web|first=Klemen |last=L |url= http://www.dutcheastindies.webs.com/blackburn.html |title=Brigadier Arthur Seaforth Blackburn |date=1999–2000 |work=Forgotten Campaign: The Dutch East Indies Campaign 1941–1942}} He ceased legal practice in 1940. He was appointed to command the [[2/3rd Machine Gun Battalion (Australia)|2/3rd Machine Gun Battalion]], which fought under his command in [[Syria-Lebanon Campaign|Syria]] against the [[Vichy French]] in 1941. Blackburn, as the senior Allied officer present, accepted the surrender of [[Damascus]] on 21 June, and after the campaign was a member of the Allied Control Commission for Syria. In February 1942, Blackburn landed with a small Australian force in [[Java]]. There he was promoted to brigadier and appointed to command 'Black Force', to assist the Dutch against the rapid Japanese advance. After three weeks' vigorous but fruitless resistance, and in spite of Blackburn's reluctance, the Allied forces surrendered on 9 March 1942.{{cite web|first=Klemen|last=L |url= http://www.dutcheastindies.webs.com/java.html |title= The conquest of Java Island, March 1942 |date=1999–2000 |work=Forgotten Campaign: The Dutch East Indies Campaign 1941–1942}} Blackburn was the senior officer of the Black Force prisoner group, which included 300 Australian seamen from {{HMAS|Perth|D29|6}}. He remained a prisoner of war until September 1945 when he was liberated in [[Mukden]], [[Manchuria]], weak but not broken in health. In 1946 he was made a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] for his distinguished service in Java.[[London Gazette]]: [http://www.gazettes-online.co.uk/ViewPDF.aspx?pdf=37585&geotype=London&gpn=2613&type=ArchivedSupplementPage&all=&exact=&atleast=&similar= (Supplement) no. 37585, page 2613], 28 May 1946 He received his discharge in 1946. [[File:Blackburn vc.jpg|thumb|Blackburn's grave]] ==Later life== In 1947–55 Blackburn served as a conciliation commissioner in the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration, and again as State president of the [[Returned and Services League]] from 1946–1949. For his services to the community, he was appointed a [[Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George]] in 1955. Blackburn died on 24 November 1960 at [[Crafers, South Australia]] from a ruptured aneurism of the common iliac artery, and was buried in the Australian Imperial Force section of Adelaide's [[West Terrace Cemetery]]. His [[List of Australian Victoria Cross recipients|Victoria Cross]] is displayed at the [[Australian War Memorial]], Canberra. He was a freemason.[http://www.lodgedevotion.net/devotionnews/education-editorial-articles/famous-australian-freemasons/large-list-of-notable-and-famous-australian-freemasons/Famous%20Australian%20Freemasons%202015%2001%2009%20with%20index.pdf?attredirects=0&d=1 Famous &/or Notable Australian Freemasons]{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Honours and awards== Blackburn was awarded:

{{Multiple issues| {{technical|date=October 2011}} {{essay|date=October 2011}} }}
'''Artificial intuition''' is a [[theory|theoretical]] capacity of an [[artificial]] software to function similarly to human [[consciousness]], specifically in the capacity of human consciousness known as [[Intuition (psychology)|intuition]].
==Comparison of human and the theoretically artificial == Intuition is the function of the mind, the experience of which, is described as knowledge based on "a hunch", resulting (as the word itself does) from "contemplation" or "insight". <ref>Eugene Sadler-Smith - [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=cVnNIB89_nIC&printsec=frontcover&dq=intuition&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiBiMPq2sLdAhUIgVwKHYWqALAQ6AEIRDAF#v=onepage&q=intuition&f=false Inside Intuition] - [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=cVnNIB89_nIC p.3] Routledge, 6 Aug 2012 {{ISBN|1134121830}} Accessed 17th September 2018</ref><ref>[https://www.etymonline.com/word/intuition etymonline] Accessed 17th September 2018</ref>
Psychologist [[Jean Piaget]] showed that intuitive functioning within the normally developing human child at the ''Intuitive Thought Substage'' of the [[preoperational stage]] occurred at from four to seven years of age.<ref>Psychology: The Science of Mind and Behaviour, Richard Gross {{ISBN|978-1-4441-0831-6}} see: [[Jean Piaget]]</ref><ref>Santrock, John W. (2004). Life-Span Development (9th Ed.). Boston, MA: McGraw-Hill College - Chapter 8 ''from'' [[Piaget's theory of cognitive development]]</ref> In Carl Jung's concept of [[synchronicity]], the concept of "intuitive intelligence" is described as something like a capacity that transcends ordinary-level functioning to a point where information is understood with a greater depth than is available in more simple rationally-thinking entities.<ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/search?qt=wikipedia&q=isbn%3A0670032921 worldcat] retrieved 11:03(GMT) 26.10.201</ref><ref>[http://www.thefreedictionary.com/synchronicity ''Farlex''] retrieved 11:08(GMT) 26.10.2011</ref><ref name="Jung 1921">Jung, C.G. ([1921] 1971). Psychological Types, Collected Works, Volume 6, Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. {{ISBN|0-691-01813-8}}.</ref><ref>Jung, Carl (2006). The Undiscovered Self: The Problem of the Individual in Modern Society. (''introduction'') {{ISBN|0-451-21860-4}}. see also : ''the [[Unconscious mind]]''</ref><ref>The Essential Jung: Selected Writings (with an introduction by [[Anthony Storr]]) {{ISBN|0-00-653065-6}}</ref>
Artificial intuition is theoretically (or otherwise) a sophisticated function of an artifice that is able to interpret data with depth and locate hidden factors functioning in [[Gestalt psychology]],<ref>[http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0167487002002076 Herbert Simon. Artificial intelligence as a framework for understanding intuition by Roger Frantz] {{doi|10.1016/S0167-4870(02)00207-6}} retrieved 11:03(UTC) 27.10.2011 see also: [[Herbert A. Simon]]</ref><ref>''Gestalt psychology'': [[Christian von Ehrenfels]], [[Kurt Koffka]] & [[Wolfgang Köhler]]</ref> and that intuition in the artificial mind would, in the context described here, be a [[Top-down and bottom-up design|bottom-up process]] upon a macroscopic scale identifying something like the [[archetypal]]<ref name="Jung 1921"/> (see [[Wikt:τύπος|τύπος]]<ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3Dtu%2Fpos Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott, A Greek-English Lexicon] retrieved 11:21(UTC) 27.10.2011</ref>).
To create artificial intuition supposes the possibility of the re-creation of a higher functioning of the human mind, with capabilities such as what might be found in [[semantic memory]] and learning.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=2WNIDwnKlDwC&pg=PA433&lpg=PA433&dq=artificial+intuition&source=bl&ots=E-RCAO2jIZ&sig=njxFJC5_vMLab6gfT742PSBQpck&hl=en&ei=tPymTue9IMWY8QOpy-DTDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CB0Q6AEwADgU#v=onepage&q=artificial%20intuition&f=false Fuzzy Information and Engineering Volume 1 Chapter titled ''Crime pattern study and fuzzy Information Analysis'' (Springer, 2008)] By Bing-Yuan Cao 19:17(GMT) 25.10.2011 ''see also'':[[Fuzzy logic]]</ref><ref>[http://monicasmind.com/?page_id=2 Monica Anderson (research company website)] retrieved 12:23(GMT) 26.10.2011</ref><ref>[http://goonth.posterous.com/?tag=artificialintuition website by Gunther Sonnenfeld] retrieved 19:36(GMT) 25.10.2011</ref> The transferral of the functioning of a biological system to synthetic functioning is based upon modeling of functioning from knowledge of [[cognition]] and the [[brain]],<ref>[http://sulcus.berkeley.edu/FLM/SH/MDL/GAL/GalDisChapts/galdis.chapter1.html sulcus.berkeley.edu] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331051928/http://sulcus.berkeley.edu/FLM/SH/MDL/GAL/GalDisChapts/galdis.chapter1.html |date=March 31, 2012 }} retrieved 20:57(GMT) 25.10.2011</ref><ref>[http://www.itp.edu/about/carl_jung.php ITP] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111025135704/http://www.itp.edu/about/carl_jung.php |date=October 25, 2011 }} retrieved 20:52(GMT) 25.10.2011</ref> for instance as applications of models of [[artificial neural network]]s from the research done within the discipline of [[computational neuroscience]].<ref>Schwartz, Eric (1990). Computational neuroscience. Cambridge, Mass: MIT Press. {{ISBN|0-262-19291-8}}.</ref>
==Application software contributing to its development== The notion of a process of a data-interpretative [[Wikt:synthesis|synthesis]] has already been found in a [[Computational linguistics|computational-linguistic]] software application that has been created for use in an internal security context.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CzqTFncZb0Q Video lecturer: Shmuel Bar, CEO and Founder] (secondary source) retrieved 19:26(GMT) 25.10.2011</ref><ref>[http://videos.syntience.com/ "Artificial Intuition" Technology for Security and Defense Applications, Israel Uploaded by TAUVOD on 25 Sep 2011] (secondary source) retrieved 19:30(GMT) 25.10.2011</ref> The software integrates computed data based specifically on objectives incorporating a paradigm described as "religious intuitive"<ref>[http://www.religion-online.org/showarticle.asp?title=3001 Roland Faber : Professor of Systematic Theology at the University of Vienna, from ''Process Studies'', pp.195-211, Vol. 28, Number 3-4, Fall-Winter, 1999](secondary source) (''in situ'') 12:21(UTC)27.10.2011</ref> ([[hermeneutic]]<ref>{{ISBN|978-0-8014-8564-0}}, 27.10.2011 see also: [[Martin Heidegger]] and [[Richard Polt]]</ref><ref>[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/hermeneutics/#Beginnings Ramberg, Bjørn and Gjesdal, Kristin, "Hermeneutics", The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Summer 2009 Edition), Edward N. Zalta (ed.) ](secondary source) 09:50(UTC) 27.10.2011</ref>),<ref>[http://www.smithsdetection.com/1025_4194.php (primary source)© Copyright 2011 Smiths Detection. A Part of Smiths Group plc. All Rights Reserved] retrieved 09:12(UTC) 27.10.2011</ref> functional to a degree that represents advances upon the performance of ''generic lexical'' data mining.<ref>[http://www.intuview.com/ company website] (primary source) retrieved 19:41(GMT) 25.10.2011</ref><ref>[https://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2008/10/tech-firms-face/ Nathan Hodge October 31, 2008 ] retrieved 19:31(GMT) 25.10.2011</ref>
Veeramachaneni and others at [[MIT]] developed a machine which performed comparably to humans in a test of intuitive intelligence during 2015.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3276604/Artificial-intelligence-breakthrough-intuition-algorithm-beats-humans-data-test.html Artificial intelligence breakthrough as intuition algorithm beats humans in data test] ''Daily Mail'' 27 October 2015 Retrieved 02 June 2016</ref>
==In fiction== [[Artificial intelligence in fiction]] often crosses the line to apparent artificial intuition, although it can't be shown if the intent of the fiction creator was to show a simulation of intuition or that real artificial intuition is part of the story's AI, because this depends on the internal structure of the programming of the AI, which is not usually shown in stories.
* ''[[The Terminator]]'', (James Cameron, Gale Anne Hurd, [[William Wisher, Jr.]]) – in ''The Terminator'', it's unclear whether the machines had a form of intuition or that all their processes were programmed. * ''[[Data (Star Trek)|Star trek]]'', (written by [[Gene Roddenberry]])– Data is a humanoid who shows artificial intelligence, but it can't be shown he is showing artificial intuition, since his programming is not disclosed.<ref>[http://www.intuitiontester.com/M.%20Zilberman.%20The%20Public%20Testing%20of%20Artificial%20Intuition%20Device%20Using%20Pick%203%20Lottery.pdf ''Abstract of a paper written by'' Mark Zilbermann] retrieved 19:45(GMT) 25.10.2011 see also: [[algorithms]]</ref> * ''[[Blade Runner]]'' – ([[P.K. Dick]]) (Hampton Fancher & David Peoples)<ref>Codification Division, Office of Legal Affairs, United Nations (18 May 2005). [https://www.un.org/law/cloning/ "Ad Hoc Committee on an International Convention against the Reproductive Cloning of Human Beings". United Nations.] retrieved 21:14(UTC) 26.10.2011( 2007-01-28).</ref><ref>[http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/british/impermissible?q=impermissible dictionary.cambridge.org] (tertiary source) retrieved 12:32(UTC) 26.10.2011</ref> if Deckard and other replicants were actually "replicas" of humans, then they undoubtedly must have had intuition. However, it's not clear what type of brain the replicants had, and if these were 100% similar to human brains.<ref>[http://www.brmovie.com/FAQs/BR_FAQ_Terminology.htm BR.movie website] 13:56(UTC) 26.10.2011 [from previous]</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Use British English|date=August 2016}} {{onesource|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox person |name = Basil Sydney |image = Rj59.jpg |caption = Basil Sydney and [[Doris Keane]] as Romeo and Juliet |occupation = Actor |birth_date = {{birth date|1894|04|23|df=y}} |birth_place = [[St Osyth]], [[Essex]], England |death_date = {{death date and age|1968|01|10|1894|04|23|df=y}} |death_place = [[London]], England |death_cause = [[Pleurisy]] |years_active = 1920-1964 |spouse = {{marriage|Doris Keane
|1918|1925|end=div}}
[[Mary Ellis]]
(m. 1929; div. 19??)
[[Joyce Howard]]
(m. 19??-19??) }} '''Basil Sydney''' (23 April 1894 – 10 January 1968) was an English stage and screen actor. ==Career== Sydney made his name in 1915 in the [[London]] stage hit ''[[Romance (Sheldon play)|Romance]]'' by Edward Sheldon, opposite the play's [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] star [[Doris Keane]], and costarred with Keane in the [[Romance (1920 film)|1920 silent film]] of the play. The couple married in 1918, and when Keane revived ''Romance'' in [[New York City|New York]] in 1921, Sydney made his [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] debut in the parts. He stayed in [[New York City|New York]] for over a decade playing classical roles like Mercutio in ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' (1922), Richard Dudgeon in ''[[The Devil's Disciple]]'' (1923), the title role in ''[[Hamlet]]'' (1923), Prince Hal in ''[[Henry IV, Part I]]'' (1926), and Petruchio in ''[[Taming of the Shrew]]'' (1927).{{cn|date=April 2015}} He made over fifty screen appearances, most memorably as [[King Claudius|Claudius]] in [[Laurence Olivier]]'s 1948 film of ''[[Hamlet (1948 film)|Hamlet]].'' He also appeared in classic films like ''[[Treasure Island (1950 film)|Treasure Island]]'' (1950), ''[[Ivanhoe (1952 film)|Ivanhoe]]'' (1952), and ''[[Around the World in Eighty Days (1956 film)|Around the World in Eighty Days]]'' (1956), but the focus of his career was the legitimate stage on both sides of the Atlantic. ==Personal life== In 1925, Sydney divorced Keane; four years later, in 1929, he married actress [[Mary Ellis]], and the couple moved to England. There he concentrated more on film than on theatre work. In the 1940s, he married English film actress [[Joyce Howard]]; they had three children. A heavy smoker, Sydney died from [[pleurisy]] in 1968, aged 73. ==Filmography== {{Div col}} * ''[[Romance (1920 film)|Romance]]'' (1920) as Armstrong * ''[[Red Hot Romance]]'' (1922) as Rowland Stone * ''[[The Midshipmaid]]'' (1932) as Cmdr. {{Infobox NFL player |image=Bill Romanowski.jpg |caption=Romanowski in December 2006 |number=53 |position=[[Linebacker]] |birth_date={{birth date and age|1966|4|2|}} |birth_place=[[Rockville, Connecticut]] |height_ft=6 |height_in=4 |weight_lbs=255 |draftyear=1988 |draftround=3 |draftpick=80 |high_school=[[Rockville High School (Connecticut)|Vernon (CT) Rockville]] |college=[[Boston College Eagles football|Boston College]] |teams= * [[San Francisco 49ers]] ([[1988 NFL season|1988]]–[[1993 NFL season|1993]]) * [[Philadelphia Eagles]] ([[1994 NFL season|1994]]–[[1995 NFL season|1995]]) * [[Denver Broncos]] ([[1996 NFL season|1996]]–[[2001 NFL season|2001]]) * [[Oakland Raiders]] ([[2002 NFL season|2002]]–[[2003 NFL season|2003]]) |highlights= * 4× [[Super Bowl]] champion ([[Super Bowl XXIII|XXIII]], [[Super Bowl XXIV|XXIV]], [[Super Bowl XXXII|XXXII]], [[Super Bowl XXXIII|XXXIII]]) * 2× [[Pro Bowl]] ([[1997 Pro Bowl|1996]], [[1999 Pro Bowl|1998]]) |statlabel1=[[Tackle (football move)|Tackles]] |statvalue1=1,116 |statlabel2=[[Quarterback sack|Sacks]] |statvalue2=39.5 |statlabel3=[[Interceptions]] |statvalue3=18 |statlabel4=[[Forced fumbles]] |statvalue4=16 |nfl=ROM323001 |HOF= |CollegeHOF= }}
'''William Thomas Romanowski''' (born April 2, 1966) is a former [[American football]] [[linebacker]]. He played in the [[National Football League]] (NFL) for the [[San Francisco 49ers]], [[Philadelphia Eagles]], [[Denver Broncos]], and [[Oakland Raiders]].
== Early life and education == Romanowski was born in [[Vernon, Connecticut|Vernon]], [[Connecticut]]. He graduated from [[Rockville High School (Connecticut)|Rockville High School]] in 1984 and [[Boston College]] in 1988 with academic honors, and was a Scanlan Award recipient.
== NFL career == Romanowski went on to a 16-year career in the [[National Football League|NFL]], playing for the [[San Francisco 49ers]] (1988–1993), [[Philadelphia Eagles]] (1994–1995), [[Denver Broncos]] (1996–2001), and [[Oakland Raiders]] (2002–2003). After his career, he was listed by [[ESPN]] as the fifth dirtiest player in professional team sports history.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Dirtiest professional team players|url = http://espn.go.com/page2/s/list/dirtiest/players.html|website = ESPN|access-date = 2016-02-08}}</ref>
Romanowski played [[List of most consecutive starts and games played by National Football League players#Consecutive games played|243 consecutive games]] during the 1988-2003 seasons,<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Redskins Blog {{!}} Romanowski: Fletcher Deserves Record|url = http://www.redskins.com/?campaign=was:fanshare:facebook|access-date = 2016-02-08}}</ref> an NFL record that stood until [[Chris Gardocki]] broke it during the 2006 season, finishing his career with 265, (256 reg. season and 9 playoff games). He won 4 [[Super Bowl]] Championships, and played 5 Super Bowls ([[Super Bowl XXIII]], [[Super Bowl XXIV]], [[Super Bowl XXXII]], [[Super Bowl XXXIII]] and [[Super Bowl XXXVII]]).
During his 16-year career, Romanowski compiled 1,105 tackles, 39.5 sacks, 18 forced fumbles, and 18 interceptions, which he returned for a net total of 98 yards and 1 career touchdown. Romanowski was a [[Pro Bowl]] selection twice, in 1996 and 1998, both during his tenure with the Denver Broncos.
=== Altercations === Romanowski was involved in numerous altercations with both teammates and opponents. In 1995, while with the Eagles, he was ejected from a game — and subsequently fined $4,500 — for kicking [[Arizona Cardinals]] fullback [[Larry Centers]] in the head.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Romanowski Hits A Nerve|url = http://articles.courant.com/1998-01-21/sports/9801210666_1_bill-romanowski-cardinals-fullback-larry-centers-head-five-times|website = The Courant|access-date = 2016-02-08}}</ref>
Two more incidents occurred during the 1997 season while he played for the Broncos. In the first, he was fined $20,000 after a helmet-to-helmet hit on then-[[Carolina Panthers]] quarterback [[Kerry Collins]] in a preseason game resulting in Collins sustaining a broken jaw.<ref name=":0" />
In the second incident, Romanowski spat in the face of 49ers wide receiver [[J. J. Stokes]] in a regular-season game played in December on a [[Monday Night Football|Monday night]] in response to Stokes' taunting.<ref name="taipei">{{cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/sport/archives/2003/12/27/2003085389|title=Bill Romanowski: golden boy of NFL or common ruffian?|publisher=}}</ref>
Two years later, while still with the Broncos, he was fined a total of $42,500 for three illegal hits plus a punch thrown at [[Kansas City Chiefs]] tight end [[Tony Gonzalez]], and was also fined an undisclosed amount for throwing a football at [[Bryan Cox]] of the [[New York Jets]], the ball hitting him in [[groin attack|the crotch area]].<ref name="sfist">{{cite web|url=http://sfist.com/2007/04/16/why_all_the_bill_romanowski_love.php|title=Why all the Bill Romanowski Love?|work=SFist|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070522004426/http://www.sfist.com/2007/04/16/why_all_the_bill_romanowski_love.php|archivedate=2007-05-22|df=}}</ref>
==== Marcus Williams incident ==== In 2003, Romanowski attacked and injured one of his teammates, [[Marcus Williams (tight end)|Marcus Williams]], during a scrimmage. Williams, a backup tight end for the Oakland Raiders, was forced to retire after Romanowski confronted Williams after a play, ripped off his helmet, and crushed his eye socket with a punch.<ref>Injured ex-Raider raises issue of ' 'roid rage' http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=1976461</ref>
Williams sued for damages of $3.4 million, arguing that Romanowski had been suffering from "[[roid rage]]" when he attacked him. Williams was awarded $340,000 for lost wages and medical expenses by a jury.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = Williams awarded $340K in Romanowski trial|url = http://espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2019325|website = ESPN.com|access-date = 2016-02-08}}</ref> Williams was quoted as saying he and his lawyers "just wanted to prove what was right and wrong about football".<ref name="sfgate">http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2005/03/23/ROMO.TMP</ref> Williams's attorney said he was very pleased with the verdict.<ref name=":1" />
==== Racism allegations ==== Romanowski has been accused of being racist at many points during his career and after retirement. Various media critics have pointed to his fines for actions including kicking [[Larry Centers]] in the head in 1995, spitting on San Francisco 49er receiver [[J.J. Stokes]] in 1997, and ripping Eddie George's helmet off in 2002, as evidence.<ref>{{cite web|title=Romanowski rages at racist allegations|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=20000817&id=nY9XAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QPIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5688,5774562&hl=en|website=www.spokane.net|publisher=The Spokesman-Review|accessdate=8 February 2016|ref=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ugly Plays: Most Racist Moments in Sports|url=http://www.bet.com/news/sports/photos/2014/04/most-racist-moments-in-sports.html#!042814-sports-comments-racist-Bill-Romanowski|website=BET|publisher=Black Entertainment Television LLC|accessdate=8 February 2016|ref=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Mossman|first1=John|title=Romanowski: 'SI article absolute lie'|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2026&dat=20000817&id=msEjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BdEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1619,1940863&hl=en|accessdate=8 February 2016|work=Moscow-Pulman Daily News|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Associated Press|date=17 Aug 2000|ref=1}}</ref>
Romanowski called [[Carolina Panthers]] starting quarterback [[Cam Newton]] "boy" in a tweet after Newton's team lost in [[Super Bowl 50]] and Newton conducted a very brief press interview.<ref name="King">{{cite web|last1=King|first1=Shaun|title=King: Bill Romanowski was blatantly racist even before he called Cam Newton ‘boy’ in post-Super Bowl tweet|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/king-bill-romanowski-calling-cam-newton-boy-racist-article-1.2523980|website=New York Daily News|publisher=NYDailyNews.com|accessdate=8 February 2016|ref=1}}</ref> He later apologized after he was accused of being racist.<ref name="King"/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Newton|first1=David|title=Cam Newton showing heartache after Super Bowl loss isn't necessarily a bad thing|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/carolina-panthers/post/_/id/19612/that-cam-newton-showed-his-hurt-after-super-bowl-loss-isnt-necessarily-a-bad-thing|website=ESPN GO|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=8 February 2016|ref=1}}</ref>
==Post-NFL career== Romanowski co-authored an autobiography in 2005 titled ''Romo My Life on the Edge: Living Dreams and Slaying Dragons''. The book became a ''[[New York Times]]'' best selling book in 2005.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Adam Schefter - ESPN MediaZone|url = http://espnmediazone.com/us/bios/schefter_adam/|website = ESPN MediaZone|access-date = 2016-02-08|language = en-US}}</ref> It chronicles his childhood, college, and his playing times in the NFL.
He was featured on the cover of the Midway Games title ''[[Blitz: The League]]'' and adds his voice as Bruno Battaglia, a linebacker in the game who wears his 53. He also appears in NCAA Football Series indirectly as LB #53 for the 1984 Boston College Eagles.
In 2006, he founded [http://www.nutrition53.com/pages/about Nutrition 53], a nutritional supplement company. He is also a minority owner of [[NASCAR]]'s [[Swan Racing]] in 2013. His own company Nutrition53 sponsored the team in 10 races in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nascar.com/en_us/news-media/articles/2013/01/31/former-nfl-lb-romanowski-joins-swan-racing.html|title=Former NFL LB Romanowski joins Swan Racing|work=[[NASCAR]]|date=2013-01-31|accessdate=2013-02-01}}</ref>
=== Football === In 2008, Romanowski was the defensive coordinator for the Piedmont High School (California) Highlanders Freshman Football team, where his son played.
In January 2009, Romanowski threw his name into the search for [[Mike Shanahan]]'s replacement as the head coach of the [[Denver Broncos]]. Romanowski sent a 30-page [[PowerPoint]] presentation to team owner [[Pat Bowlen]], but was not considered for the job.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|title = Broncos not planning to meet with Romanowski|url = http://espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3836598|website = ESPN.com|access-date = 2016-02-08}}</ref> The job was ultimately given to [[Josh McDaniels]].<ref name=":2" />
===BALCO Scandal=== Romanowski and his wife were investigated for prescription drug fraud, though the charges were later dropped.<ref name="findarticles">{{cite web|url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4191/is_20020222/ai_n10001652|title = FindArticles.com - CBSi|publisher = }}</ref> Records seized by the government belonging to the [[Bay Area Laboratory Co-operative]], later discovered to be the source of a designer steroid, indicate that he had used the [[anabolic steroid]] "[[the clear|The Clear]]" and [[testosterone (medication)|synthetic testosterone]] ointment "[[the cream|The Cream]]" provided by BALCO since 2003. Romanowski admitted to staying a step ahead of NFL drug testing policies.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title = Clayton: Staying in the game|url = http://espn.go.com/nfl/columns/story?id=2070102&columnist=clayton_john|website = ESPN.com|access-date = 2016-02-08}}</ref> In an October 16, 2005 appearance on ''[[60 Minutes]]'', Romanowski admitted to using steroids and human growth hormone that he received from [[Victor Conte]], BALCO owner.<ref name="usatoday">{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/balco-timeline.htm|title=BALCO investigation timeline - USATODAY.com|publisher=}}</ref>
===In media=== Romanowski starred in the remake of ''[[The Longest Yard (2005 film)|The Longest Yard]]'' as one of the prison guards.<ref name=":3" />
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Footballstats |nfl=ROM323001 |espn=252 |cbs=4179 |yahoo=1787 |si=1787 |pfr=R/RomaBi00}} *{{IMDb name| id=1665399 | name=Bill Romanowski }}

page.title: Capital punishment in the Czech Republic

revision.text:
[[Capital punishment]] (''trest smrti'' in [[Czech language|Czech]]) is forbidden by the [[Charter of Fundamental Rights and Freedoms]] of the [[Czech Republic]] (part of the constitutional law of the Czech Republic) and is simultaneously prohibited by international legal obligations arising from the Czech Republic's membership of both the [[Council of Europe]] and the [[European Union]].
Historically the capital punishment was legal, and was used, when the [[Czech Socialist Republic|Czech Republic]] was part of [[Czechoslovak Socialist Republic|Czechoslovak Federation]], until the punishment was abolished by amendment of the federal criminal code in 1990. The last execution was carried out in 1989.
== History and methods of capital punishment == Capital punishment was common under the [[Austrian Monarchy]], with a short exception from 1787 to 1795 under the rule of [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor|Joseph II]], in [[Austria-Hungary]], and from 1918 in the newly created Czechoslovakia. During the period from 1918 to 1989, a total of 1,217<ref>Due to the certain chaos in historical records, the actual number may be slightly different. The above-mentioned numbers also don't include people executed during the [[Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia|German occupation]] of the [[Czech lands]] from 1939 to 1945 or during the existence of the [[Slovak State]]. The period of occupation introduced also many other methods of execution (apart from the hanging and firing squad) such as [[guillotine]], [[lethal injection]] and [[gas chamber]]. See Liška, Otakar; a kolektiv (2006). Tresty smrti vykonané v Československu v letech 1918–1989. Praha: Úřad dokumentace a vyšetřování zločinů komunismu. pp. 261–262) </ref> people were executed legally, the majority of them (61%) [[Pursuit of Nazi collaborators|immediately after World War II]], many others (21%) were executed from [[Political crime|political reasons]] during the [[History of Czechoslovakia (1948–89)#Stalinization|terror in early years of communist rule]] and the rest of the executed people were convinced criminals (18%).<ref name="Liška">{{cite book|last1=Liška|first1=Otakar|last2=a kolektiv|title=Tresty smrti vykonané v Československu v letech 1918–1989|date=2006|publisher=Úřad dokumentace a vyšetřování zločinů komunismu|location=Praha|isbn=80-86621-09-X|pages=261–262|language=Czech}}</ref>
The common method of execution during the whole period was [[Hanging#Pole method|pole hanging]]. Other methods of hanging or [[firing squad]] were rare. Following the abolition of the open-air execution areas in 1954, a execution cell was built in the basement of the [[Pankrác Prison]], where executions were carried out until 1989. The device in Pankrác's "death chamber" was a simple [[noose]] attached to the wall with the remotely operated [[trapdoor]] in the floor.<ref name="aha">{{cite journal|last1=Novotný|first1=Petr|title=Rozhovor s posledním českým katem! Před popravou rvačka, po ní panák rumu...|journal=AHA online.cz|date=28 July 2007|url=http://www.ahaonline.cz/clanek/trapasy/14717/rozhovor-s-poslednim-ceskym-katem-pred-popravou-rvacka-po-ni-panak-rumu.html|accessdate=12 April 2017|trans-title=Interview with the last Czech executioner! Before the execution brawl after shot of rum ...|language=Czech|issn=1213-8991}}</ref>
=== First Czechoslovak Republic (1918–1938) === During the presidency of [[Tomáš Garrigue Masaryk]] (1918–35) 16 people were executed, incl. 4 for military [[treason]]. Masaryk was an opponent of capital punishment and had the privilege of commuting death sentences, one he exercised frequently. His successor [[Edvard Beneš]] signed the death sentences for 8 people, incl. 3 for military [[treason]]. After his resignation 2 more criminals were executed before the occupation of the country.
=== German occupation (1939–1945) === During the time of [[German occupation of Czechoslovakia|German occupation]] thousands were executed and hundreds of thousands were killed without any trial. Though the [[summary execution]]s happened only rare (in comparation to other countries occupied by Germans), such occasions happened nearly every year (see the [[List of massacres in the Czech Republic#Massacres during World War II|massacres in during World War]]). In Prague [[Pankrác prison]] 1079 were [[guillotine]]d or hanged, about 550 were shot in [[Kobylisy Shooting Range|Prague-Kobylisy]], about 800 were shot or hanged in [[Brno]], about 300 were shot or hanged in [[Theresienstadt concentration camp|Theresienstadt-Small Fortress]] etc. Hundreds of Czech people were also tried and executed in German prisons, such as Dresden (846 people) or [[Berlin-Plötzensee]] (677 people). Thousands other were killed by hanging, gas chambers or shot in the [[Nazi concentration camps]].<ref name="Fronta">{{cite web|last1=Šír|first1=Vojtěch|title=Popraviště v protektorátu Čechy a Morava|url=http://www.fronta.cz/dotaz/popraviste-v-protektoratu-cechy-a-morava|website=Fronta.cz|accessdate=12 April 2017|language=Czech|date=10 March 2010}}</ref>
In the period of German occupation, only 3 criminals were sentenced to death and executed by Czech courts.<ref name="Liška"/>
=== Postwar retribution (1945–1948) === After World War II, based on the [[Beneš decrees]], special courts at the local level (''lidové soudy'', ''people's courts'') were set up to punish [[war crimes]] and [[Collaboration with the Axis Powers during World War II|collaboration]]. Until 1948 they sentenced 713 people to death. Another 10 people were executed for common crimes.<ref name="Liška"/>
=== Communist Czechoslovakia (1948-1989) === During the presidency of [[Klement Gottwald]] (1948–53) 237 people were executed, of whom over 190 for political crimes. Gottwald pardoned 18 people. Among the best known of those executed are [[Milada Horáková]], a politician, hanged in 1950. The widely publicised [[Prague Trials]] with former party's [[general secretary]] [[Rudolf Slánský]] resulted in 11 executions.<ref name="Liška"/>
During this period hundreds of other people died due to cruel conditions in prisons and concentration camps such as the [[Concentration camp in Jáchymov]].
During the presidency of [[Antonín Zápotocký]] (1953–57) 94 people were executed. That figure fell to 87 people during [[Antonín Novotný]]'s presidency (1957–68), 14 people during the presidency of [[Ludvík Svoboda]] (1968–1975, including a period during which Prime Minister [[Lubomír Štrougal]] acted as President in ill Svodoba's absence) and then to 38 people during that of [[Gustáv Husák]] (1975–89).<ref name="Liška"/>
From 1954 to 1968 all executions were carried out in [[Pankrác Prison]], [[Prague]]; after 1968 some took place in [[Bratislava]]. In 1956 the number of crimes punishable by death was reduced and mandatory review of sentences was introduced. In 1961 a law made the conditions for capital punishment more strict, with only especially brutal murders punishable by death. The last execution in Czechoslovakia took place on 8 June 1989, when [[Štefan Svitek]] was hanged in Bratislava prison for triple murder; in today's Czech Republic the last executed person was [[Vladimír Lulek]], hanged on 2 February 1989 in Pankrác Prison for murder of his wife and four children. The last person sentenced to death was Zdeněk Vocásek, but his sentence was changed to life imprisonment in 1990.
=== Abolition of the capital punishment === Soon after the Communist party [[Velvet Revolution|fell from power]] in 1989 the new president [[Václav Havel]] pushed the abolition of the capital punishment through parliament. A May 1990 criminal law reform replaced capital punishment with [[life imprisonment]]. Furthermore in January 1991 capital punishment became prohibited by the [[Charter of Fundamental Rights and Freedoms]], which became part of the [[1960 Constitution of Czechoslovakia|Czechoslovak]] constitutional law and since the [[Dissolution of Czechoslovakia|dissolution of Czechoslovakia]] remains part of the [[Constitution of the Czech Republic|Czech constitutional law]].
Capital punishment in the [[Czech Republic]] is simultaneously prohibited by international legal obligations arising from the Czech Republic's membership of both the [[Council of Europe]] and the [[European Union]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071011104232/http://www.mvcr.cz/policie/udv/sesity/sesit2/sesit2.doc List of all people executed in Czechoslovakia, historical background, laws, bibliography] (in Czech, [[MS Word]] document, [https://web.archive.org/web/20071011104232/www.mvcr.cz/policie/udv/sesity/sesit2/sesit2.doc HTML version] by Google) {{capital punishment}} {{Capital punishment in Europe}}
