revision.text:
'''Cell potency''' is a [[Cell (biology)|cell's]] ability to [[Cellular differentiation|differentiate]] into other cell types {{cite journal |authors=Mahla RS| title = Stem cells application in regenerative medicine and disease threpeutics | journal = International Journal of Cell Biology | volume = 2016 | issue = 7 | pages = 19 | year = 2016 | pmid = 27516776 | doi = 10.1155/2016/6940283 }}{{Cite book|title=Human biotechnology as Social Challenge |editor=Nikolaus Knoepffler |editor2=Dagmar Schipanski |editor3=Stefan Lorenz Sorgner |page=28 |chapter=The Potential of Stem Cells: An Inventory |author=Hans R. Schöler |publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd. |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-7546-5755-2}}{{cite web|url=http://www.stemcellschool.org/glossary.html#P|title=Stem Cell School: Glossary|format=|work=|accessdate=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161007145004/http://www.stemcellschool.org/glossary.html#P#P|archive-date=2016-10-07|dead-url=yes|df=}} The more cell types a cell can differentiate into, the greater its potency. Potency is also described as the gene activation potential within a cell, which, like a continuum, begins with [[totipotency]] to designate a cell with the most differentiation potential, [[pluripotency]], [[multipotency]], [[oligopotency]], and finally [[unipotency]]. [[File:Stem cells diagram.png|300px|thumb|right|[[Pluripotent]], embryonic [[stem cell]]s originate as inner mass cells within a [[blastocyst]]. These stem cells can become any tissue in the body, excluding a [[placenta]]. Only the [[morula|morula's]] cells are [[totipotent]], able to become all tissues and a placenta.]] ==Totipotency== Totipotency (Lat. ''totipotentia,'' "ability for all [things]") is the ability of a single [[cell (biology)|cell]] to divide and produce all of the differentiated cells in an [[organism]]. [[Spore]]s and [[zygote]]s are examples of totipotent cells.{{Cite journal |title=Totipotency, pluripotency and nuclear reprogramming |vauthors=Mitalipov S, Wolf D |author-link=Shoukhrat Mitalipov |journal=Advances in Biochemical Engineering/Biotechnology |year=2009 |volume=114 |pages=185–199 |pmid=19343304 |pmc=2752493 |doi=10.1007/10_2008_45 |isbn=978-3-540-88805-5 |bibcode=2009esc..book..185M }} In the spectrum of cell potency, totipotency represents the cell with the greatest [[Cellular differentiation|differentiation]] potential, being able to differentiate into any [[Embryo|embryonic]] cell, as well as extraembryonic cells. In contrast, pluripotent cells can only differentiate into embryonic cells.{{Cite book|title=Molecular Cell Biology, 8th Ed|last=Lodish|first=Harvey|publisher=W. H. Freeman|year=2016|isbn=978-1319067748|location=|pages=975-977}}{{Cite web|url=https://stemcell.ny.gov/faqs/what-difference-between-totipotent-pluripotent-and-multipotent|title=What is the difference between totipotent, pluripotent, and multipotent?|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} It is possible for a fully differentiated cell to return to a state of totipotency.{{cite journal |author=Western P |title=Foetal germ cells: striking the balance between pluripotency and differentiation |journal=Int. J. Dev. Biol. |volume=53 |issue=2–3 |pages=393–409 |year=2009 |pmid=19412894 |doi=10.1387/ijdb.082671pw |url=}} This conversion to totipotency is complex, not fully understood and the subject of recent research. Research in 2011 has shown that cells may differentiate not into a fully totipotent cell, but instead into a "complex cellular variation" of totipotency.{{cite journal |vauthors=Sugimoto K, Gordon SP, Meyerowitz EM |title=Regeneration in plants and animals: dedifferentiation, transdifferentiation, or just differentiation? |journal=Trends Cell Biol. |volume=21 |issue=4 |pages=212–218 |date=April 2011 |pmid=21236679 |doi=10.1016/j.tcb.2010.12.004 |url=}} Stem cells resembling totipotent [[blastomere]]s from 2-cell stage embryos can arise spontaneously in mouse embryonic stem cell cultures{{cite journal|author=Macfarlan T.S.|author2=Gifford W.D.|author3=Driscoll S.|author4=Lettieri K.|author5=Rowe H.M.|author6=Bonanomi D.|author7=Firth A.|author8=Singer O.|author9=Trono D.|author10=Pfaff S.L.|last-author-amp=yes |year=2012|title=Embryonic stem cell potency fluctuates with endogenous retrovirus activity|journal=Nature|volume=487|pages=57–63|doi=10.1038/nature11244|pmid=22722858|pmc=3395470|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v487/n7405/full/nature11244.html|bibcode=2012Natur.487...57M}}{{cite journal|author=Morgani S.M.|author2=Canham M.A.|author3=Nichols J.|author4=Sharov A.A.|author5=Migueles R.P.|author6=Ko M.S.|author7=Brickman J.M.|last-author-amp=yes|year=2013|title=Totipotent Embryonic Stem Cells Arise in Ground-State Culture Conditions|journal=Cell Rep|volume=3|pages=1945–1957|doi=10.1016/j.celrep.2013.04.034|pmid=23746443|pmc=3701323}} and also can be induced to arise more frequently ''in vitro'' through down-regulation of the [[chromatin]] assembly activity of [[CAF-1]].{{cite journal|author=Ishiuchi T.|author2=Enriquez-Gasca R.|author3=Mizutani E.|author4=Boskovic A.|author5=Ziegler-Birling C.|author6=Rodriguez-Terrones D.|author7=Wakayama T.|author8=Vaquerizas J.M.|author9=Torres-Padilla M.E.|last-author-amp=yes|year=2015|title=Early embryonic-like cells are induced by downregulating replication dependent chromatin assembly|journal=Nat Struct Mol Biol|volume=22|issue=9|pages=662–671|doi=10.1038/nsmb.3066|pmid=26237512}} The human development model is one which can be used to describe how totipotent cells arise.{{cite journal |vauthors=Seydoux G, Braun RE |title=Pathway to totipotency: lessons from germ cells |journal=Cell |volume=127 |issue=5 |pages=891–904 |date=December 2006 |pmid=17129777 |doi=10.1016/j.cell.2006.11.016 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0092867406014723}} Human development begins when a [[spermatozoon|sperm]] fertilizes an egg and the resulting fertilized egg creates a single totipotent cell, a [[zygote]].{{cite journal |vauthors=Asch R, Simerly C, Ord T, Ord VA, Schatten G |title=The stages at which human fertilization arrests: microtubule and chromosome configurations in inseminated oocytes which failed to complete fertilization and development in humans |journal=Hum. Reprod. |volume=10 |issue=7 |pages=1897–1906 |date=July 1995 |pmid=8583008 |doi= 10.1093/oxfordjournals.humrep.a136204|url=}} In the first hours after fertilization, this zygote divides into identical totipotent cells, which can later develop into any of the three germ layers of a human ([[endoderm]], [[mesoderm]], or [[ectoderm]]), or into cells of the [[placenta]] ([[cytotrophoblast]] or [[syncytiotrophoblast]]). After reaching a 16-cell stage, the totipotent cells of the [[morula]] differentiate into cells that will eventually become either the [[blastocyst]]'s [[Inner cell mass]] or the outer [[trophoblast]]s. Approximately four days after fertilization and after several cycles of cell division, these totipotent cells begin to specialize. The inner cell mass, the source of [[embryonic stem cells]], becomes pluripotent. Research on ''[[Caenorhabditis elegans]]'' suggests that multiple mechanisms including [[post-transcriptional regulation|RNA regulation]] may play a role in maintaining totipotency at different stages of development in some species.{{cite journal|last=Ciosk|first=R.|title=Translational Regulators Maintain Totipotency in the Caenorhabditis elegans Germline|journal=Science|date=10 February 2006|volume=311|issue=5762|pages=851–853|doi=10.1126/science.1122491|pmid=16469927|bibcode=2006Sci...311..851C|last2=Depalma|first2=Michael|last3=Priess|first3=James R.}} Work with [[zebrafish]] and mammals suggest a further interplay between [[miRNA]] and [[RNA-binding protein]]s (RBPs) in determining development differences.{{cite journal |vauthors=Kedde M, Agami R |title=Interplay between microRNAs and RNA-binding proteins determines developmental processes |journal=Cell Cycle |volume=7 |issue=7 |pages=899–903 |date=April 2008 |pmid=18414021 |doi= 10.4161/cc.7.7.5644|url=}} ==Pluripotency== [[File:Human embryonic stem cells.png|thumb|250px|A: Human [[embryo]]nic stem cells (cell colonies that are not yet differentiated).
B: [[Nerve]] cells]] {{Hatnote|For substances having the capacity to produce several distinct biological responses see [[Pluripotency (biological compounds)]]}} {{Main|Stem cell}} In cell biology, pluripotency (Lat. ''pluripotentia,'' "ability for many [things]"){{cite web|title=Biology Online|url=http://www.biology-online.org/dictionary/Pluripotent|publisher=Biology-Online.org|accessdate=25 April 2013}} refers to a stem cell that has the potential to [[cellular differentiation|differentiate]] into any of the three [[germ layers]]: endoderm (interior stomach lining, gastrointestinal tract, the lungs), mesoderm (muscle, bone, blood, urogenital), or ectoderm (epidermal tissues and nervous system).{{cite book|editor-last=Binder |editor-first=Marc D. |title=Encyclopedia of neuroscience |year=2009 |publisher=Springer |location=Berlin |isbn=978-3540237358 |editor2=Hirokawa, Nobutaka |editor3=Uwe Windhorst}} However, cell pluripotency is a continuum, ranging from the completely pluripotent cell that can form every cell of the embryo proper, e.g., embryonic stem cells and iPSCs (see below), to the incompletely or partially pluripotent cell that can form cells of all three germ layers but that may not exhibit all the characteristics of completely pluripotent cells. ===Induced pluripotency=== {{Main|Induced pluripotent stem cells}} Induced pluripotent stem cells, commonly abbreviated as iPS cells or iPSCs, are a type of pluripotent [[stem cell]] artificially derived from a non-pluripotent cell, typically an adult [[somatic cell]], by inducing a "forced" expression of certain [[gene]]s and [[transcription factor]]s.{{Cite journal | last = Baker | first = Monya | title = Adult cells reprogrammed to pluripotency, without tumors | journal = Nature Reports Stem Cells | date = 2007-12-06 | url = http://www.nature.com/stemcells/2007/0712/071206/full/stemcells.2007.124.html | doi = 10.1038/stemcells.2007.124 }} These transcription factors play a key role in determining the state of these cells and also highlights the fact that these somatic cells do preserve the same genetic information as early embryonic cells.{{cite journal|last=Stadtfeld|first=M.|author2=Hochedlinger, K.|title=Induced pluripotency: history, mechanisms, and applications|journal=Genes & Development|date=15 October 2010|volume=24|issue=20|pages=2239–2263|doi=10.1101/gad.1963910|pmc=2956203}} The ability to induce cells into a pluripotent state was initially pioneered in 2006 using mouse fibroblasts and four transcription factors, [[Oct4]], [[Sox2]], [[Klf4]] and c-[[Myc]];{{cite journal|last=Takahashi|first=Kazutoshi|author2=Yamanaka, Shinya|title=Induction of Pluripotent Stem Cells from Mouse Embryonic and Adult Fibroblast Cultures by Defined Factors|journal=Cell|date=August 2006|volume=126|issue=4|pages=663–676|doi=10.1016/j.cell.2006.07.024|pmid=16904174}} this technique, called [[reprogramming]], earned [[Shinya Yamanaka]] and [[John Gurdon]] the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 2012."[https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/2012/ The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 2012]". Nobelprize.org. Nobel Media AB 2013. Web. 28 Nov 2013. This was then followed in 2007 by the successful induction of human iPSCs derived from human dermal fibroblasts using methods similar to those used for the induction of mouse cells.{{cite journal|last=Takahashi|first=Kazutoshi|author2=Tanabe, Koji |author3=Ohnuki, Mari |author4=Narita, Megumi |author5=Ichisaka, Tomoko |author6=Tomoda, Kiichiro |author7= Yamanaka, Shinya |title=Induction of Pluripotent Stem Cells from Adult Human Fibroblasts by Defined Factors|journal=Cell|date=1 November 2007|volume=131|issue=5|pages=861–872|doi=10.1016/j.cell.2007.11.019|pmid=18035408}} These induced cells exhibit similar traits to those of embryonic stem cells (ESCs) but do not require the use of embryos. Some of the similarities between ESCs and iPSCs include [[pluripotency]], [[morphology (biology)|morphology]], self-renewal ability, a trait that implies that they can divide and replicate indefinitely, and [[gene expression]].{{cite journal|last=Liang|first=Gaoyang|author2=Zhang, Yi|title=Embryonic stem cell and induced pluripotent stem cell: an epigenetic perspective|journal=Cell Research|date=18 December 2012|volume=23|issue=1|pages=49–69|doi=10.1038/cr.2012.175|pmid=23247625|pmc=3541668}} [[Epigenetic]] factors are also thought to be involved in the actual reprogramming of somatic cells in order to induce pluripotency. It has been theorized that certain [[epigenetic]] factors might actually work to clear the original somatic [[epigenetic]] marks in order to acquire the new epigenetic marks that are part of achieving a [[pluripotent]] state. Chromatin is also reorganized in iPSCs and becomes like that found in ESCs in that it is less condensed and therefore more accessible. [[Euchromatin]] modifications are also common which is also consistent with the state of [[euchromatin]] found in ESCs. Due to their great similarity to ESCs, iPSCs have been of great interest to the medical and research community. iPSCs could potentially have the same therapeutic implications and applications as ESCs but without the controversial use of embryos in the process, a topic of great bioethical debate. In fact, the induced [[pluripotency]] of [[somatic cell]]s into [[cellular differentiation|undifferentiated]] [[induced pluripotent stem cell|iPS cells]] was originally hailed as the end of the [[Stem cell controversy|controversial use]] of [[embryonic stem cell]]s. However, iPSCs were found to be potentially [[tumorigenic]], and, despite advances, were never approved for clinical stage research in the United States. Setbacks such as low replication rates and early senescence have also been encountered when making iPSCs,{{cite web|last=Choi|first=Charles|title=Cell-Off: Induced Pluripotent Stem Cells Fall Short of Potential Found in Embryonic Version|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=cell-induced-pluripotent|publisher=Scientific American|accessdate=25 April 2013}} hindering their use as ESCs replacements. Additionally, it has been determined that the somatic expression of combined [[transcription factor]]s can directly induce other defined somatic cell fates ([[transdifferentiation]]); researchers identified three neural-lineage-specific transcription factors that could directly convert mouse [[fibroblasts]] (skin cells) into fully functional [[neuron]]s.{{cite journal |vauthors=Vierbuchen T, Ostermeier A, Pang ZP, Kokubu Y, Südhof TC, Wernig M |title=Direct conversion of fibroblasts to functional neurons by defined factors |journal=Nature |volume=463 |issue=7284 |pages=1035–1041 |year=2010 |pmid=20107439 |pmc=2829121 |doi=10.1038/nature08797 |bibcode=2010Natur.463.1035V }} This result challenges the terminal nature of [[cellular differentiation]] and the integrity of lineage commitment; and implies that with the proper tools, ''all'' cells are [[totipotent]] and may form all kinds of tissue. Some of the possible medical and therapeutic uses for iPSCs derived from patients include their use in cell and tissue transplants without the risk of rejection that is commonly encountered. iPSCs can potentially replace animal models unsuitable as well as ''in vitro'' models used for disease research.{{cite journal|last=Park|first=IH|author2=Lerou, PH |author3=Zhao, R |author4=Huo, H |author5= Daley, GQ |title=Generation of human-induced pluripotent stem cells.|journal=Nature Protocols|year=2008|volume=3|issue=7|pages=1180–1186|pmid=18600223|doi=10.1038/nprot.2008.92}} ===Naive vs. primed pluripotency states=== Recent findings with respect to [[epiblast]]s before and after implantation have produced proposals for classifying pluripotency into two distinct phases: "naive" and "primed".{{cite journal |vauthors=Nichols J, Smith A |title=Naive and primed pluripotent states |journal=Cell Stem Cell |volume=4 |issue=6 |pages=487–492 |year=2009 |pmid=19497275 |doi=10.1016/j.stem.2009.05.015 |url=}} The baseline stem cells commonly used in science that are referred as Embryonic stem cells (ESCs) are derived from a pre-implantation epiblast; such epiblast is able to generate the entire fetus, and one epiblast cell is able to contribute to all cell lineages if injected into another blastocyst. On the other hand, several marked differences can be observed between the pre- and post-implantation epiblasts, such as their difference in morphology, in which the epiblast after implantation changes its morphology into a cup-like shape called the "egg cylinder" as well as chromosomal alteration in which one of the X-chromosomes undergoes random inactivation in the early stage of the egg cylinder, known as [[X-inactivation]].{{cite journal |vauthors=Heard E |title=Recent advances in X-chromosome inactivation |journal=Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. |volume=16 |issue=3 |pages=247–255 |year=2004 |pmid=15145348 |doi=10.1016/j.ceb.2004.03.005 |url=}} During this development, the egg cylinder epiblast cells are systematically targeted by [[Fibroblast growth factors]], [[Wnt signaling pathway|Wnt]] signaling, and other inductive factors via the surrounding yolk sac and the trophoblast tissue,{{cite journal |vauthors=Beddington RS, Robertson EJ |title=Axis development and early asymmetry in mammals |journal=Cell |volume=96 |issue=2 |pages=195–209 |year=1999 |pmid=9988215 |doi= 10.1016/s0092-8674(00)80560-7|url=}} such that they become instructively specific according to the spatial organization.{{cite journal |vauthors=Lawson KA, Meneses JJ, Pedersen RA |title=Clonal analysis of epiblast fate during germ layer formation in the mouse embryo |journal=Development |volume=113 |issue=3 |pages=891–911 |year=1991 |pmid=1821858 |doi= |url=}} Another major difference that was observed, with respect to cell potency, is that post-implantation epiblast stem cells are unable to contribute to blastocyst [[chimera (genetics)|chimera]]s,{{cite journal |vauthors=Rossant J |title=Stem cells and early lineage development |journal=Cell |volume=132 |issue=4 |pages=527–531 |year=2008 |pmid=18295568 |doi=10.1016/j.cell.2008.01.039 |url=}} which distinguishes them from other known pluripotent stem cells. Cell lines derived from such post-implantation epiblasts are referred to as [[epiblast-derived stem cells]] which were first derived in laboratory in 2007; despite their nomenclature, that both ESCs and EpiSCs are derived from epiblasts, just at difference phases of development, and that pluripotency is still intact in the post-implantation epiblast, as demonstrated by the conserved expression of [[Homeobox protein NANOG|Nanog]], [[Fut4]], and [[Oct-4]] in EpiSCs,{{cite journal |vauthors=Brons IG, Smithers LE, Trotter MW, Rugg-Gunn P, Sun B, Chuva de Sousa Lopes SM, Howlett SK, Clarkson A, Ahrlund-Richter L, Pedersen RA, Vallier L |title=Derivation of pluripotent epiblast stem cells from mammalian embryos |journal=Nature |volume=448 |issue=7150 |pages=191–195 |year=2007 |pmid=17597762 |doi=10.1038/nature05950 |url=|bibcode=2007Natur.448..191B }} until [[somitogenesis]] and can be reversed midway through induced expression of [[Oct-4]].{{cite journal |vauthors=Osorno R, Tsakiridis A, Wong F, Cambray N, Economou C, Wilkie R, Blin G, Scotting PJ, Chambers I, Wilson V |title=The developmental dismantling of pluripotency is reversed by ectopic Oct4 expression |journal=Development |volume=139 |issue=13 |pages=2288–2298 |year=2012 |pmid=22669820 |pmc=3367440 |doi=10.1242/dev.078071 |url=}} ==Multipotency== {{Further|Progenitor cells}} [[File:Hematopoiesis (human) diagram en.svg|thumb|Hematopoietic stem cells are an example of multipotency. When they differentiate into myeloid or lymphoid progenitor cells, they lose potency and become oligopotent cells with the ability to give rise to all cells of its lineage.]] Multipotency describes [[progenitor cell]]s which have the gene activation potential to differentiate into discrete cell types. For example, a multipotent [[blood]] stem cell —and this cell type can differentiate itself into several types of blood cell types like [[lymphocytes]], [[monocytes]], [[neutrophils]], etc., but it is still ambiguous whether HSC possess the ability to differentiate into [[brain cells]], [[bone cells]] or other non-blood cell types.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} New research related to multipotent cells suggests that multipotent cells may be capable of conversion into unrelated cell types. In another case, human umbilical cord blood stem cells were converted into human neurons.{{cite journal |vauthors=Giorgetti A, Marchetto MC, Li M, Yu D, Fazzina R, Mu Y, Adamo A, Paramonov I, Cardoso JC, Monasterio MB, Bardy C, Cassiani-Ingoni R, Liu GH, Gage FH, Izpisua Belmonte JC |title=Cord blood-derived neuronal cells by ectopic expression of Sox2 and c-Myc |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. |volume=109 |issue=31 |pages=12556–61 |year=2012 |pmid=22814375 |pmc=3412010 |doi=10.1073/pnas.1209523109|bibcode=2012PNAS..10912556G }} Research is also focusing on converting multipotent cells into [[pluripotent]] cells.{{cite journal |vauthors=Guan K, Nayernia K, Maier LS, Wagner S, Dressel R, Lee JH, Nolte J, Wolf F, Li M, Engel W, Hasenfuss G |title=Pluripotency of spermatogonial stem cells from adult mouse testis |journal=Nature |volume=440 |issue=7088 |pages=1199–203 |year=2006 |pmid=16565704 |doi=10.1038/nature04697 |bibcode=2006Natur.440.1199G }} Multipotent cells are found in many, but not all human cell types. Multipotent cells have been found in [[cord blood]], {{cite journal|author=Yong Zhao|author2=Theodore Mazzone |title=Human cord blood stem cells and the journey to a cure for type 1 diabetes |journal=Autoimmun Rev |volume=10 |issue=2 |pages=103–107 |date=Dec 2010 |pmid=20728583 |doi=10.1016/j.autrev.2010.08.011}} adipose tissue,{{cite journal |author=Tallone T |title=Adult human adipose tissue contains several types of multipotent cells |journal=J Cardiovasc Transl Res |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=200–10 |date=April 2011 |pmid=21327755 |doi=10.1007/s12265-011-9257-3 |url=|author2= Realini C |author3= Böhmler A |display-authors=etal}} cardiac cells,{{cite journal |author=Beltrami AP |title=Adult cardiac stem cells are multipotent and support myocardial regeneration |journal=Cell |volume=114 |issue=6 |pages=763–76 |date=September 2003 |pmid=14505575 |doi= 10.1016/S0092-8674(03)00687-1|url=|author2= Barlucchi L |author3= Torella D |display-authors=etal}} bone marrow, and [[mesenchymal stem cell]]s (MSCs) which are found in the [[third molar]].{{cite journal |vauthors=Ohgushi H, Arima N, Taketani T |title=[Regenerative therapy using allogeneic mesenchymal stem cells] |language=Japanese |journal=Nippon Rinsho |volume=69 |issue=12 |pages=2121–7 |date=December 2011 |pmid=22242308 |doi= |url=}} MSCs may prove to be a valuable source for stem cells from molars at 8–10 years of age, before adult dental calcification. MSCs can differentiate into osteoblasts, chondrocytes, and adipocytes.{{cite journal|last=Uccelli|author2=Moretta, Pistoia|title=Mesenchymal stem cells in health and disease|journal=Nature Reviews Immunology|date=September 2008|volume=8|issue=9|pages=726–36|doi=10.1038/nri2395|pmid=19172693|first1=Antonio}} ==Oligopotency== In biology, oligopotency is the ability of [[progenitor cell]]s to differentiate into a few [[cell types]]. It is a degree of [[stem cell#Potency definition|potency]]. Examples of oligopotent stem cells are the lymphoid or myeloid stem cells. A lymphoid cell specifically, can give rise to various blood cells such as B and T cells, however, not to a different blood cell type like a red blood cell.{{cite web|last=Ibelgaufts|first=Horst|title=Cytokines & Cells Online Pathfinder Encyclopedia|url=http://www.copewithcytokines.de/|accessdate=25 April 2013}} Examples of progenitor cells are vascular stem cells that have the capacity to become both [[endothelial]] or smooth muscle cells. ==Unipotency== {{Further|Precursor cell}} In [[cell biology]], a unipotent cell is the concept that one stem cell has the capacity to differentiate into only one cell type. It is currently unclear if true unipotent stem cells exist. Hepatoblasts, which differentiate into [[hepatocytes]] (which constitute most of the [[liver]]) or [[cholangiocytes]] (epithelial cells of the bile duct), are bipotent.{{cite web|title=hepatoblast differentiation|url=http://gowiki.tamu.edu/wiki/index.php/Category:GO:0061017_!_hepatoblast_differentiation|work=GONUTS}} A close synonym for ''unipotent cell'' is ''[[precursor cell]].'' ==See also== {{portal|Molecular and cellular biology}} * [[Induced stem cells]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{cell potency}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cell Potency}} [[Category:Developmental biology]] [[Category:Cell biology]] [[Category:Stem cells]]

{{Infobox state representative |name = Charles Turbiville |image = |image_size= |state_house=South Dakota |district = 31st |alongside = |term_start = 2017 |term_end = October 20, 2018 |term_start1=2005 |term_end1=2013 |predecessor= |successor= |birth_date = {{birth date|1943|7|13}} |birth_place =[[Buffalo, South Dakota]], U.S. |death_date = {{death date and age|2018|10|20|1943|7|13}} |death_place =[[Deadwood, South Dakota]], U.S. |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = |children =3 |relations= |alma_mater= }} '''Charles M. Turbiville''' (July 13, 1943 – October 20, 2018) was an American politician.
==Background== Turbiville was born in [[Buffalo, South Dakota]]. He graduated from [[Newell High School]] in [[Newell, South Dakota]]. Turbiville went to [[Black Hills State University]] and [[University of South Dakota]]. Turbiville served in the [[United States Army]] from 1969 to 1969 and was a commissioned a second lieutenant. He was a farmer and owned his parents farm in Newell, South Dakota. He served on the Newell School Board. Turbiville served as director of economic development for [[Deadwood, South Dakota]]. From 2013 to 2016, Turbiville served on the South Dakota Lottery Commission.<ref>[http://www.fidler-isburgfuneralchapels.com/obituary/charles-turbiville Charles Turbiville-obituary]</ref>
==Political career== Turbiville served as mayor of Deadwood, South Dakota from 2013 until his death. He also served as a Republican member for the 31st district in the [[South Dakota House of Representatives]] from 2005 to 2013, and again starting from 2017 until his death on October 20, 2018. He died at his home in Deadwood, South Dakota.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sdlegislature.gov/Legislators/Historical_listing/LegislatorDetail.aspx?MemberID=3757|title=SDLRC - Charles M. Turbiville|website=www.sdlegislature.gov}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://votesmart.org/candidate/biography/48386/charles-turbiville#.V-NYZJMrL_Q|title=The Voter's Self Defense System|website=Vote Smart}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/south-dakota/articles/2018-10-21/deadwood-mayor-state-rep-chuck-turbiville-dies-at-75|title = Deadwood Mayor, State Rep. Chuck Turbiville Dies at 75|website = [[U.S. News & World Report]]|date = October 21, 2018|accessdate = October 21, 2018}}</ref> He was reelected to his state house seat on November 6, two and a half weeks after his death, which will be filled by an appointee of the [[Governor of South Dakota]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sdsucollegian.com/2018/11/07/south-dakota-voters-elect-late-candidate/|title = South Dakota voters elect late candidate |website = The Collegian |date = November 7, 2018|accessdate = November 26, 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Turbiville, Charles}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:People from Deadwood, South Dakota]] [[Category:People from Butte County, South Dakota]] [[Category:People from Harding County, South Dakota]] [[Category:Military personnel from South Dakota]] [[Category:Businesspeople from South Dakota]] [[Category:Farmers from South Dakota]] [[Category:Black Hills State University alumni]] [[Category:University of South Dakota alumni]] [[Category:South Dakota Republicans]] [[Category:School board members in South Dakota]] [[Category:Mayors of places in South Dakota]] [[Category:Members of the South Dakota House of Representatives]] [[Category:21st-century American politicians]] [[Category:Politicians elected posthumously]] [[Category:Missing middle or first names]]
{{SouthDakota-politician-stub}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=March 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} [[File:AsiaticCheetahCubs.jpg|thumb|right|[[Asiatic cheetah]] cubs with a [[dog]] in [[Dharwar]], [[British India]], 1897.]] '''Reintroduction of the cheetah in India''' involves the re-establishment of a population of [[cheetah]]s into areas where they had previously existed but were hunted into extinction from the [[Mughal Period]] onwards, largely by Indian royalty, until the early 20th century when only several thousand remained.<ref name="Telegraph">{{cite web |title=India to reintroduce cheetah 60 years after 'extinction' |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/earth/wildlife/5779336/India-to-reintroduce-cheetah-60-years-after-extinction.html |website=[[Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref> A part of the reintroduction process is the identification and restoration of their former grassland scrub forest habitats.<ref name="governancenow.com">Karnad, D.Plan well to reintroduce Cheetah. http://governancenow.com/views/columns/plan-well-reintroduce-cheetah/</ref> This is within the scope of the duties of the local forest department of each State, where relocation occurs, through the use of Indian Central Government funding.
==Background==
===History=== [[File:AkbarHunt.jpg|thumb|right|A painting depicting [[Akbar the Great|Akbar]], the third Mughal emperor, hunting with locally trapped Indian cheetahs, c. 1602.]] Until the 20th century, the [[Asiatic cheetah]] was quite common and roamed all the way from [[Israel]], the [[Arabian Peninsula]] to [[Iran]], [[Afghanistan]] and [[India]]. In India, they ranged as far south as the [[Tirunelveli district]] of Tamil Nadu. The Asiatic cheetah, also known as the "hunting leopard" in India was kept by kings and princes to hunt [[gazelle]]; the [[Mughal Empire|Mughal]] emperor [[Akbar]] kept them for hunting gazelle and [[blackbuck]]s. He was said to have had 1,000 cheetahs at one time for assisting in his royal hunts, a number believed to be overestimated by many sources. Trapping of large numbers of adult Indian cheetahs, who had already learned hunting skills from wild mothers, for assisting in royal hunts is said to be another major cause of the species rapid decline in India as they never bred in captivity with only one record of a litter ever.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.binoygupta.com/wildlife/cheetah-275/ |title=| Travel India Guide |publisher=Binoygupta.com |date=18 May 2012 |accessdate=16 May 2013}}</ref>
====Extinction==== [[File:CheetahHunt.jpg|thumb|Hunting of [[blackbuck]] with Indian cheetah; Drawn by James Forbes in South [[Gujarat]], India. Oriental Memoirs, 1812.]] By the beginning of the twentieth century, the species was already heading for extinction in many areas. The last physical evidence of the Asiatic cheetah in India was thought to be three, all shot by the Maharajah Ramanuj Pratap Singh Deo of [[Surguja State]] in 1947, in eastern [[Madhya Pradesh]] or northern [[Chhattisgarh]],<ref name=Divyabhanusinh>{{cite book |author= Divyabhanusinh |year=1999 |title=The End of a Trail: the Cheetah in India |publisher=Banyan Books, New Delhi}}</ref> but a female was sighted in [[Koriya district]], in what is now Chhattisgarh, in 1951.<ref name=Divyabhanusinh/>
[[File:Maharajah Ramanuj Pratap Singh Deo with cheetah kill 1948 BNHS.jpg|thumb|Maharajah Ramanuj Pratap Singh Deo shot three of the last cheetahs in India in 1948, in [[Surguja State]], [[Madhya Pradesh]]. His private secretary submitted this photo to the [[Journal of the Bombay Natural History Society]].<ref name=Divyabhanusinh/>]]
In India in the mid-20th century, prey was abundant, and cheetahs fed on the [[blackbuck]], the [[chinkara]], and sometimes the [[chital]] and the [[nilgai]].
{{quote|...is in low, isolated, rocky hills, near the plains on which live antelopes, its principal prey. It also kills gazelles, nilgai, and, doubtless, occasionally deer and other animals. Instances also occur of sheep and goats being carried off by it, but it rarely molests domestic animals, and has not been known to attack men. Its mode of capturing its prey is to stalk up to within a moderate distance of between one to two hundred yards, taking advantage of inequalities of the ground, bushes, or other cover, and then to make a rush. Its speed for a short distance is remarkable far exceeding that of any other beast of prey, even of a greyhound or kangaroo-hound, for no dog can at first overtake an Indian antelope or a gazelle, either of which is quickly run down by ''C. jubatus'', if the start does not exceed about two hundred yards. General McMaster saw a very fine hunting-leopard catch a black buck that had about that start within four hundred yards. It is probable that for a short distance the hunting-leopard is the swiftest of all mammals.|Blanford writing on the Asiatic Cheetah in India quoted by Lydekker<ref>Lydekker, R. A. 1893-94. The Royal Natural History. Volume 1</ref>}}
With the death of the last remaining population of the Asiatic cheetah in India, the species was declared extinct in India; it is the only animal in recorded history to become extinct from India due to unnatural causes.<ref name="Rajasthan to be home for cheetahs">{{cite web |author=Dey, A. |publisher=[[Times of India]] |title=Rajasthan to be home for cheetahs |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-07-26/flora-fauna/28154728_1_cheetahs-fastest-animal-wild-fowls |date=2009-07-16 |accessdate=2009-08-09}}</ref> A consequence of the extinction of the cheetahs and subsequently the Indian royalty that prized them was that their grasslands homes came to be controlled, used and managed by local people. "The grasslands faded and diminished under the hooves of a thousand cattle, they were tilled and ploughed until only a few scattered remnants were preserved in the form of wildlife sanctuaries". [[File:CheetahCubs.jpg|thumb|Asiatic cheetah cubs in Dharwar, 1897]]
==Reintroduction efforts==
=== Cloning=== During the early 2000s, Indian scientists from the [[Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology]] (CCMB), [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]], proposed a plan to clone [[Asiatic cheetah]]s obtained from Iran. India requested Iran to transport one live pair to India. If not possible, Indian scientists requested Iran to allow them to collect some live cells of the cheetah pair in Iran itself, which can then be made into living cell lines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/oldStory/17389/ |title=CCMB’s Iran hope for Asiatic cheetah |work=The Indian Express|date=28 January 2003 |accessdate=16 May 2013}}</ref>
However, Iran refused saying that it would neither send any cheetahs to India nor would they allow Indian scientists to collect their tissue samples. It is said that Iran wanted an [[Asiatic lion]] in exchange for a cheetah and that India was not willing to export any of its lions.<ref name="Rajasthan to be home for cheetahs"/> In 2009, the Indian government contacted Iran again to explore the possibility of Iran supplying cheetahs to help to re-establish their presence on the subcontinent decades after they were hunted to extinction. The Iranian embassy in Delhi had said that its government was in the process of "arranging" talks.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lamont |first=James |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/c5792cd0-81da-11de-9c5e-00144feabdc0.html |title=India tries cheetah diplomacy on Iran |publisher=FT.com |date=5 August 2009 |accessdate=16 May 2013}}</ref>
==Possible reintroduction sites== Currently, wildlife experts have shortlisted three regions which have the potential to support cheetah populations. The [[Nauradehi Wildlife Sanctuary]] and [[Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary|Kuno-Palpur Wildlife Sanctuaries]] in Madhya Pradesh and the [[Shahgarh Landscape|Shahgarh bulge landscape]] in Jaisalmer, Rajasthan<ref>{{cite news| url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/NEWS/Environment/Flora-Fauna/Rajasthan-to-be-home-for-cheetahs/articleshow/4821200.cms | work=The Times of India | title=Rajasthan to be home for cheetahs | date=26 July 2009}}</ref> have been declared potentially suitable for the reintroduction of the cheetah. The Kuno-Palpur Wildlife Sanctuary in Madhya Pradesh has the potential to hold populations of four of India's [[big cat]]s; the [[Bengal tiger]], [[Indian leopard]], and Asiatic lion and cheetah, all four of which have co-existed in the same habitats historically for many years, before they were wiped out due to overhunting and habitat destruction. Since the Shahgarh Landscape is fenced along the Indo-[[Pakistan]]i border region, the addition of more fencing will ensure adequate protection for the cheetah population. The Nauradehi Wildlife Sanctuary (1197km2) is part of a much larger forested landscape (5500km2 ) which can host the cheetah as well.<ref>[http://www.wildlifetrustofindia.org/pages/cheetah-report.pdf Assessing the potential for reintroducing the cheetah in India, 2010.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927004033/http://www.wildlifetrustofindia.org/pages/cheetah-report.pdf# |date=27 September 2011 }} A report on the feasibility of cheetah reintroduction in India, jointly prepared by the [[Wildlife Trust of India]] (WTI) and [[Wildlife Institute of India]] (WII), and submitted to the [[Ministry of Environment and Forests (India)|Ministry of Environment and Forests, Government of India]] ([[MK Ranjitsinh Jhala|Ranjitsinh, M. K. & Jhala]], Y. V. (2010) Assessing the potential for reintroducing the cheetah in India. Wildlife Trust of India, Noida, & the Wildlife Institute of India, Dehradun, TR2010/001). Also available at WII website: [http://www.wii.gov.in/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=385:assessing-the-potential-for-reintroducing-the-cheetah-in-india-tr-2010001&catid=76:announcements], [http://www.wii.gov.in/index.php?view=article&catid=76%3Aannouncements&id=385%3Aassessing-the-potential-for-reintroducing-the-cheetah-in-india-tr-2010001&format=pdf&option=com_content]. Accessed 1 February 2011. Also available at Ministry of Environment and Forests (India) website: [http://moef.nic.in/downloads/public-information/Reintroducing%20the%20Cheetah%20in%20India.pdf] Accessed 20 September 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.moef.nic.in/downloads/public-information/ProjectCheetahBrochure.pdf Project Cheetah (Brochure)], September 2010, Ministry of Environment and Forests, Government of India. Accessed 1 February 2011.</ref><ref>[http://pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=63704 Three Sites Recommended for Reintroduction of Cheetah], Ministry of Environment and Forests, 28-July, 2010, Press Information Bureau (PIB), Government of India</ref>
At a future date, when sufficient population has built up, other former range habitats in India (after revitalizing them) may also be considered for reintroduction like the [[Banni grasslands]] and [[Desert National Park]]<ref>[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-07-29/ahmedabad/28280854_1_cheetah-sq-km-asiatic-lions Gujrat misses out on cheetah], 29 Jul 2010, The Times of India newspaper</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Himanshu Kaushik, TNN 3 October 2009, 01.29am IST |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-10-03/ahmedabad/28084202_1_cheetahs-sq-km-semi-wild-enclosures |title=Banni Grassland possible home for cheetahs; Himanshu Kaushik, TNN, 3 October 2009; Times of India |work=The Times of India|date=3 October 2009 |accessdate=16 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=, 03.54am IST |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-09-12/ahmedabad/28063993_1_cheetahs-yadvendradev-jhala-gajner |title=Cheetahs on their way to Gujarat?; 12 September 2009; The Times of India |work=The Times of India|date=12 September 2009 |accessdate=16 May 2013}}</ref> etc.
A few wildlife groups have suggested the Moyar river valley in [[Tamil Nadu]]'s Satyamangalam FD, part of [[Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve]] as it is a pristine forest with flourishing population of prey and a good record of conservation. Frederick Augustus Nicholson, the then British Collector has reported to have shot a few individuals near Kothamangalam, Velamundi and Bolampatti (all in NBR). This region is on the leeward side of SW monsoon.
==Genetic sub-species level differentiation== {{multiple image |direction = vertical |align = right | image1 = Cheetah Umfolozi SouthAfrica MWegmann.jpg | width1 = 200 | caption1 = [[South African cheetah]] (''Acinonyx jubatus jubatus'') | image2 = Asian cheetah.jpg | width2 = 200 | caption2 = [[Asiatic cheetah]] (''Acinonyx jubatus venaticus'') }} The Asiatic cheetah (''Acinonyx jubatus venaticus'') has, for a long time, been ''theoretically'' classified as a sub-species of the cheetah with the suffix ''"venaticus"'' applied at the end of its scientific binomial name ''Acinonyx jubatus''. However, at a cheetah reintroduction workshop organised in India on 9 September 2009, [[Stephen J. O'Brien]] from [[Laboratory of Genomic Diversity]] of [[National Cancer Institute]] of the US who has in the past conducted numerous prestigious genetic studies - including those on Asiatic lions - said that according to the latest modern genetic studies, it was discovered that the Asiatic cheetah was, in fact, genetically identical to the African cheetah with which it had separated only about 5000 years ago. This was not enough time for a [[subspecies|sub-species]] level differentiation; O'Brien said that in comparison the [[Asiatic lion|Asian]] and [[African lion]] subspecies were separated some 100,000 years ago, as was the [[African leopard|African]] and Asian [[leopard#subspecies|leopard subspecies]] 169,000 years ago. Cheetah expert [[Laurie Marker]] of the [[Cheetah Conservation Fund]] and other wildlife experts advised the Indian Government that for reintroduction purposes India should source the cheetah from Africa where they were much more numerous instead of trying to have some removed from the critically endangered low population of about 70 to 110 or so Asiatic cheetahs left in Iran.
India's Union Minister of State for Environment and Forests Jairam Ramesh, chief wildlife wardens of Rajasthan, Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh, officials of the environment ministry, cheetah experts from across the globe including Laurie Marker from Cheetah Conservation Fund, representatives from the Wildlife Institute of India (WII) including Yadvendradev Jhala, and IUCN, an international conservation NGO, among others, participated in a meeting about this issue.<ref>[http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/enviornment/experts-eye-african-cheetahs-for-reintroduction-to-submit-plan_100245817.html Experts eye African cheetahs for reintroduction (In INDIA), to submit plan]; 10 September 2009; [[Indo-Asian News Service|IANS]]; [[Thaindian]]; retrieved 29 January 2011</ref><ref>[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-09-09/flora-fauna/28074792_1_cheetah-m-k-ranjitsinh-tiger-reserves Workshop on cheetah relocation begins, views differ]; 9 September 2009; PTI; [[Times of India]]; retrieved 29 January 2011</ref>
Subsequently, in 2011, a much more detailed five-year genetic study involving gathering of DNA samples from the wild, zoos and museums in eight countries was published in ''Molecular Ecology (Journal)'' on 8 January 2011. This newer study concluded that African and Asiatic cheetahs were in reality genetically very distinct and had in fact separated 32,000 to 67,000 years ago. Sub-species level differentiation had taken place due to longer separation from the African population.<ref name="Molecular Ecology">{{cite journal|title = Phylogeography, genetic structure and population divergence time of cheetahs in Africa and Asia: evidence for long-term geographic isolates|author1=Charruau P |author2=C Fernandes |author3=P Orozco-Terwengel |author4=J Peters |author5=L Hunter |author6=H Ziaie |author7=A Jourabchian |author8=H Jowkar |author9=G Schaller |author10=S Ostrowski |doi=10.1111/j.1365-294X.2010.04986.x |year=2011| journal=Molecular Ecology |volume=20 |pages=706–724 |pmid=21214655 |pmc=3531615}}</ref><ref>[http://content.usatoday.com/communities/sciencefair/post/2011/01/three-distinct-cheetah-populations-but-irans-on-the-brink/1 Three distinct cheetah populations, but Iran's on the brink]; 18 January 2011; [[USA TODAY]]</ref><ref>[http://www.scientificamerican.com/blog/post.cfm?id=asian-cheetahs-racing-toward-extinc-2011-01-24 Asian cheetahs racing toward extinction]; 24 January 2011; [[Scientific American magazine]]; retrieved on 29 January 2011</ref><ref>[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2011/01/110117082300.htm The Need for Conservation of Asiatic Cheetahs]; 17 January 2011; [[ScienceDaily]]; retrieved on 29 January 2011</ref> The effect of this latest revelation on India's plan to reintroduce cheetahs to the country was left unknown.
===Introduction of African cheetah=== As the world's last Asiatic cheetah population in Iran is currently classified as [[critically endangered]], with an estimated total of below 100, the cheetah experts felt that it would not be conducive to disturb it. India is therefore exploring an alternate plan of importing the [[South African cheetah]] (''Acinonyx jubatus jubatus'') from some [[Africa]]n countries, such as in [[Namibia]], where they are in greater abundance, with a view to breeding them in captivity, and then setting them free in protected, semi-arid habitats in India.
Since the Asiatic cheetah became extinct in India about half a century ago, suggestions to reestablish the cheetah in India have been ongoing.<ref>[http://www.indianexpress.com/res/web/pIe/ie/daily/19981027/30050144.html Cheetahs may soon be on the prowl in Indian woods]; by Vinay Madhav; 27 October 1998; The indian express newspaper</ref><ref>[http://www.outlookindia.com/article.aspx?201053 Book Review: Pug Marks In Time - A superb book documents the history and demise of the cheetah]; by Mahesh Rangarajan; 27 March 1996; Outlook India Magazine. Also see [http://www.exoticindiaart.com/book/details/IDI060/ BOOK: The End of Trail: The Cheetah in India Third Edition; IDI060; by Divyabhanusinh; Paperback (Edition: 2006); Oxford University Press] {{ISBN|0-19-568697-7}}</ref> For this purpose a meeting of International cheetah experts was organized in Gajner, near [[Bikaner]] in the Indian state of [[Rajasthan]] during September 2009. As per the discussions held at the meeting cheetah experts from around the world favored importing [[South African cheetah]]s for the proposed reintroduction in India as against getting them from the world's last remnant population of the Asiatic cheetah, which is also called "Iranian cheetah," since it survives in Iran, where it is currently [[critically endangered]], with the entire population estimated to be below 100.<ref>[http://www.indianexpress.com/news/india-to-get-cheetahs-from-namibia/487160/ India to get cheetahs from Namibia]; by Neha Sinha; 9 July 2009; 2 Page article online; Indian Express Newspaper</ref><ref>[http://sify.com/news/cheetah-re-introduction-plan-under-discussion-news-national-jjjkkbhjfbj.html Cheetah re-introduction plan under discussion]; IANS; 2009-09-09; Sify News. See also [http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/enviornment/cheetah-re-introduction-plan-under-discussion_100244739.html]. See also [http://www.aol.in/news-story/cheetah-reintroduction-plan-under-discussion/581013]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [https://archive.is/20120713185349/http://newshopper.sulekha.com/cheetah-re-introduction-plan-under-discussion_news_1104379.htm]</ref><ref>[http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/enviornment/experts-eye-african-cheetahs-for-reintroduction-to-submit-plan_100245817.html Experts eye African cheetahs for reintroduction, to submit plan]; ICT by IANS; 11 September 2009; THAILAND NEWS; A news portal for Indians in Thailand. See also at sulekha news [https://archive.is/20120716204339/http://newshopper.sulekha.com/experts-eye-african-cheetahs-for-reintroduction-to-submit-plan_news_1105041.htm], [http://www.indiaenews.com/africa/20090911/220256.htm]</ref> International experts including Laurie Marker of [[Cheetah Conservation Fund]], credited with developing cheetah conservation programmes in a number of countries, including Iran, argues that the world's last Asiatic cheetah population in Iran is abysmally low to spare any individuals for reintroduction efforts in India. [[Stephen J. O'Brien|Stephen J O'Brien]], world's leading conservation geneticist and Chief of the Laboratory of Genomic Diversity at the [[National Cancer Institute]], United States, has clarified that there is no significant genetic difference between the African and the Iran's Asiatic cheetah, as per genetic research carried out by him African and [[Indian cheetah]]s were only separated just some 5,000 years ago which is not enough for a sub-species level differentiation. "African and Asian cheetahs are similar in nature and have same genetic make-up. So India can have the animal from South Africa if it is not getting from Iran (which has already refused to part with its Asian cheetah)," noted the cheetah genetic expert Stephen J O Brien. At the meeting experts also identified South Africa, Botswana, Kenya, Tanzania and [[UAE]] as countries from where the cheetah could be imported for India. "About 5 to 10 animals annually have to be brought to India over a period of 5 to 10 years," recommended another working group, which was formed for exploring sourcing and translocation of the cheetah.<ref name="Rajasthan to be home for cheetahs"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.outlookindia.com/article.aspx?262019 |title=Spotted: Lean Cat Rerun - Hunted out from Indian grasslands, the cheetah may tear across the landscape again; by Shruti Ravindran; environment: wildlife; Oct 05, 2009; Outlook India magazine |publisher=Outlookindia.com |accessdate=16 May 2013}}</ref><ref>[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/c5792cd0-81da-11de-9c5e-00144feabdc0.html?nclick_check=1 India tries cheetah diplomacy on Iran]; By James Lamont in New Delhi; 5 August 2009; Financial Times</ref><ref>[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-09-08/flora-fauna/28076680_1_cheetah-fastest-animal-relocation Plan for cheetah relocation in India]; PTI; 8 September 2009; Times of India</ref><ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/environment/flora-fauna/Workshop-on-cheetah-relocation-begins-views-differ-/articleshow/4991394.cms Workshop on cheetah relocation begins, views differ]; PTI; 9 September 2009; Times of India</ref><ref>[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-09-11/jaipur/28067178_1_cheetah-sq-km-shahgarh-bulge More places identified for housing cheetah]; by Anindo Dey, TNN; 11 September 2009; Times of India</ref><ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/articleshow/5000895.cms Cheetahs on their way to Gujarat?] 12 September 2009; Times of India</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8262862.stm India plans return of the cheetah - India plans to bring back the cheetah, nearly half a century after it became extinct in the country. The BBC's Soutik Biswas considers whether it is a good idea.]; 20 September 2009; BBC NEWS. Also see [https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:EeWelz1vkIkJ:the2050project.com/index2.php%3Foption%3Dcom_content%26do_pdf%3D1%26id%3D626+Asiatic+Cheetah+captive+breeding&hl=en&gl=ca&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESjgjdLum-nKhdJ2jcrLTlUMdRQiyi20pb5vlXkJpYjow1PJaW8k4Eo54Fu8lluwqQcIo2lzHFRNChZUJU3sVx2EyVovMkSdHo85E7XgwSMxVSmdRtUJ5iaJ0iVHyjUIqL3eaZ0p&sig=AHIEtbQTT0CLeyMtQvO-_ohuSu7cg39wJA]</ref>
The [[Ministry of Environment and Forests (India)|Ministry of Environment & Forests, Government of India]] has approved the recommendation for a detailed survey of potential reintroduction sites in the four Indian states of [[Rajasthan]], [[Gujarat]], [[Madhya Pradesh]] and [[Chhattisgarh]], shortlisted during the consultative meeting. Three more Indian states [[Karnataka]], [[Andhra Pradesh]] and [[Maharashtra]] are being also considered. This survey will form the basis for the roadmap of reintroduction of cheetah in India, and will be carried out by the [[Wildlife Institute of India]] (WII),.<ref>"Are the plans to bring the cheetah to India still on? / Yes, they are very much on. We have asked the Wildlife Institute of India to prepare a roadmap. We had given them three months, which will expire end of February. So the project is very much on." [http://week.manoramaonline.com/cgi-bin/MMOnline.dll/portal/ep/theWeekContent.do?sectionName=Current+Events&contentId=6586095&programId=1073754900&pageTypeId=1073754893&contentType=EDITORIAL We got our way with Obama - INTERVIEW/JAIRAM RAMESH, ENVIRONMENT AND FORESTS MINISTER (of the Central Government of India)]; By Soni Mishra; 31 JANUARY 2010; [[The Week (Indian magazine)|THEWEEK]], India</ref><ref>[http://www.zeenews.com/news569149.html EnvironMin seeks roadmap on reintroducing Cheetah]; 8 October 2009; Eco News; ZEE NEWS</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8298270.stm India agrees to cheetah survey - The Indian government has approved a survey of sites which can accommodate the cheetah, in an effort to reintroduce the animal in the country.] 9 October 2009; BBC NEWS</ref><ref>[http://www.hindu.com/2009/10/09/stories/2009100952912000.htm Ministry nod for Cheetah re-introduction project - Jairam Ramesh conveyed decision to WTI]; by Aarti Dhar; 9 October 2009; The Hindu; Online edition of India's National Newspaper, Also see [http://news.webindia123.com/news/articles/India/20091007/1357490.html]</ref>
==Current status== The Ministry of forests and environment of India is now hammering out the details of the cheetah conservation plan. As a first step, a two-day seminar of technical experts on cheetahs was held in Gajner from 9 September 2009. Experts on cheetah, including [[Divyabhanusinh Chavda]] and [[MK Ranjitsinh Jhala|M K Ranjitsinh]] presented their papers on how to go about bringing cheetahs to India.
The initial plans were to bring the cheetahs to [[Gajner Wildlife Sanctuary]]. "We want to set up a breeding ground for the cheetahs and Gajner seems to fit the bill perfectly. Thereafter, they will be transported to various states," he added.
India is also in talks with the [[Islamic Republic of Iran]] over the possibility of sending a pair of Asiatic cheetahs to India. The Iranian embassy in Delhi said that its government was in the process of "arranging" talks.<ref name="Rajasthan to be home for cheetahs"/>
The Union Minister of State for Environment and Forests Jairam Ramesh said that African cheetahs could be brought to India within three years having just returned from a trip to South Africa, one of the potential source-habitats of cheetahs to be moved to India.
The Wildlife Institute of India is spearheading the project, and will unveil a road map and destination for the African cheetahs – possible options are in Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh and Gujarat – by the end of May.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.hindu.com/2010/04/27/stories/2010042760890500.htm | location=Chennai, India | work=The Hindu | title=African cheetahs can be relocated to India in three years, says Jairam | date=27 April 2010}}</ref>
[[Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary|Kuno Palpur]] and [[Nauradehi Wildlife Sanctuary|Nauradehi Sancturies]] in Madhya Pradesh and [[Shahgarh Landscape|Shahgarh landscape]] in Jaisalmer in Rajasthan have been selected in by the Wildlife Institute of India as most suitable sites for the reintroduction project.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.outlookindia.com/item.aspx?688765 |title=Centre Clears Three Sites as Habitats for Cheetah |publisher=news.outlookindia.com |accessdate=16 May 2013 }}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===Plans on hold=== As of May 2012 the Indian Supreme Court has put the project of importing cheetahs from Africa and reintroducing them in India on hold. Some Conservationists have been fighting a legal battle in Indian Supreme Court to get the Indian State Government of [[Gujarat]] to break its monopolizing of wild Asiatic lions and release a few overpopulated prides of lions spilling out of [[Gir National Park]] for reintroduction in the [[Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary]] in the neighbouring Indian State of [[Madhya Pradesh]] which was prepared for them after relocating over 24 villages out of the forest. In the past, for last two decades the State Government of Gujarat had concocted every possible reason to maintain its monopoly on wild Asiatic lions and the tourism revenue generated by them and of recent Gujarat's legal council had put forward the argument that Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary is being used for the introduction of African cheetah which might take several years to fully settle down and repopulate the area and hence reintroduction of lions should only be done after that, this scared the conservationists that Gujarat will use this pretext to delay the [[Asiatic Lion Reintroduction Project|reintroduction of native lions]] by many more decades using the cheetah argument. Indian Supreme court has taken note of the arguments put forth by some Indian conservationists that importing African cheetah for reintroduction in India is misguided as it is against the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]]'s reintroduction guidelines and no clearance had been sought from India's [[National Board for Wildlife]]. The Indian Supreme Court has put the project on hold till further notice asking for clearance from India's National Board for Wildlife, meantime it has fast tracked the case for the re-introduction of lions to Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary and is hearing it every Monday.<ref>[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-05-09/flora-fauna/31641093_1_african-cheetahs-palpur-kuno-exotic-species Supreme Court red flags move to translocate African cheetah in India], Dhananjay Mahapatra, TNN 9 May 2012, [[The Times of India]]; [http://daily.bhaskar.com/article/GUJ-AHD-asiatic-lion-may-roar-at-new-home-in-kuno-palpur-sanctuary-3236580.html Asiatic lion may roar at new home in Kuno-Palpur sanctuary], Ahmedabad/New Delhi, 09/May/2012, [[Daily Bhaskar]]; [http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-05-08/flora-fauna/31626206_1_african-cheetah-asian-cheetahs-moef SC stays Cheetah Re-introduction Project], PTI 8 May 2012, THE TIMES OF INDIA; [http://www.thehindu.com/sci-tech/energy-and-environment/article3397756.ece Supreme Court stays Cheetah reintroduction project], NEW DELHI, 8 May 2012, [[The Hindu]]; [http://www.downtoearth.org.in/content/supreme-court-stalls-centre-s-plan-reintroduce-cheetahs-india Supreme Court stalls Centre’s plan to reintroduce cheetahs in India], 8 May 2012, [[Down to Earth (magazine)|Down To Earth]] (DTE); [http://www.deccanherald.com/content/247955/sc-stays-cheetah-re-introduction.html SC stays Cheetah Re-introduction Project], New Delhi, 8 May 2012 (PTI), [[Deccan Herald]]; [http://daily.bhaskar.com/article/GUJ-AHD-gujarat-mp-fight-for-asiatic-lions-share-3195602.html Gujarat, MP fight for Asiatic lions’ share], Source: DNA, 01/May/2012, Daily Bhaskar</ref>
Senior advocate PS Narasimha, court-appointed adviser and the ''amicus curiae'' in the Asiatic lion's relocation case in India's Supreme Court, filed an application seeking a stay on the implementation of African cheetah reintroduction project in India. The Indian Supreme court granted the stay and the matter has been scheduled for further hearing in July 2012 after the court returns from vacation. During its hearings, the Bench was informed that India's Ministry of Environment and Forests (MoEF) has decided to introduce the [[South African cheetah]] (''Acinonyx jubatus jubatus'') from [[Namibia]] into Kuno Wildlife Sanctuary in the Indian state of [[Madhya Pradesh]], the same proposed habitat being developed as the second home for the translocation of lions from Gir Wildlife Sanctuary in the neighbouring Indian state of Gujarat which did not want to shift any lions out of the state. Narasimha said the proposal for reintroduction of African cheetah "has not been either placed before the Standing Committee of India's National Board for Wildlife, nor has there been a considered decision taken in this regard". He stated in an application that "scientific studies show that the [[Southern African cheetah|African Cheetah]]s and Asian Cheetahs are completely different, both genetically and also in their characteristics" and the reintroduction of African cheetah in India was also against the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) guidelines on translocation of wildlife species. "In fact, the (IUCN) guidelines categorically warn against the introduction of alien or exotic species. The African Cheetah obviously never existed in India. Therefore, it is not case of intentional movement of an organism into a part of its native range," the application stated. Asiatic cheetah became extinct in India in the 1950s, In the past, India's last recorded cheetah in the wild was said to have been shot in the Rewa area of Madhya Pradesh in the late 1940s. It was mentioned that the introduction of alien or exotic species is universally shunned by wildlife experts and "in fact countries such as South Africa, Australia are spending huge amount of funds to eradicate and remove exotic wildlife species from wilderness areas or wild habitats". Narasimha also sought a direction of India's Ministry of Environment and Forests (MoEF) to produce before the apex court all relevant records and decisions relating to introduction of cheetah. He said the Indian cheetah in genetic composition is a different animal than the African cheetah and a different sub species altogether and "therefore one cannot be introduced in place of the other". Conservationists say fewer than 100 of the critically endangered Asiatic cheetah subspecies remain only in Iran, roaming the central deserts. The vast majority of the 7,100 cheetahs left in the world are in Africa.<ref>[http://daily.bhaskar.com/article/GUJ-AHD-asiatic-lion-may-roar-at-new-home-in-kuno-palpur-sanctuary-3236580.html Asiatic lion may roar at new home in Kuno-Palpur sanctuary], Source: DNA, 09/May/2012, Daily Bhaskar; [http://www.downtoearth.org.in/content/supreme-court-stalls-centre-s-plan-reintroduce-cheetahs-india Supreme Court stalls Centre’s plan to reintroduce cheetahs in India], Kumar Sambhav S..., 8 May 2012, Down To Earth, DTE; [http://www.deccanherald.com/content/247955/sc-stays-cheetah-re-introduction.html SC stays Cheetah Re-introduction Project], 8 May 2012, PTI, Deccan Herald</ref>

A '''confabulation''', also known as a [[False memory|false]], degraded, or corrupted memory, is a stable pattern of activation in an [[artificial neural network]] or neural assembly that does not correspond to any previously learned patterns. The same term is also applied to the (nonartificial) neural mistake-making process leading to a false memory ([[confabulation]]).
==Cognitive science== In [[cognitive science]], the generation of confabulatory patterns is symptomatic of some forms of [[brain trauma]].<ref>Gazzaniga, M. S. (1995). [https://www.hse.ru/data/2011/06/28/1216307711/Gazzaniga.%20The%20Cognitive%20Neurosciences.pdf "The Cognitive Neurosciences"], A Bradford Book, The MIT Press, Cambridge, Massachusetts.</ref> In this, confabulations relate to pathologically induced neural activation patterns depart from direct experience and learned relationships. In [[computational modeling]] of such damage, related brain [[Pathology|pathologies]] such as [[dyslexia]] and [[hallucination]] result from simulated [[lesion]]ing<ref>Plaut, D.C. (1993). [https://www.cnbc.cmu.edu/~plaut/papers/pdf/PlautShallice93CN.deepDyslexia.pdf "Deep Dyslexia: A case of connectionist neuropsychology"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303222355/https://www.cnbc.cmu.edu/~plaut/papers/pdf/PlautShallice93CN.deepDyslexia.pdf |date=2016-03-03 }}. Cognitive Neuropsychology, 10(5), 377-500.</ref> and [[neuron]] death.<ref>Yam, P. (1993). "Daisy, Daisy" Do computers have near-death experience, Scientific American, May 1993.</ref> Forms of confabulation in which missing or incomplete information is incorrectly filled in by the [[brain]] are generally modelled by the well known neural network process called pattern completion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rni.org/ftsommer/FS/neural_associative_memory.html|title=Neural associative memory|work=rni.org}}</ref>
==Neural networks== Confabulation is central to a theory of [[cognition]] and [[consciousness]] by S. L. Thaler in which thoughts and ideas originate in both biological and synthetic neural networks as false or degraded memories nucleate upon various forms of [[Neurone|neuronal]] and [[Synapse|synaptic]] fluctuations and damage.<ref>Thaler, S. L. (1997a). U.S. 5,659,666, [http://imagination-engines.com/documents/BU_Conference.pdf "Device for the Autonomous Generation of Useful Information"], Issued 8/19/1997.</ref><ref>Thaler, S. L. (1997b). [http://imagination-engines.com/iei_seminal_cognition.php "A Quantitative Model of Seminal Cognition: the creativity machine paradigm"], Proceedings of the Mind II Conference, Dublin, Ireland, 1997.</ref> Such novel patterns of neural activation are promoted to ideas as other neural nets perceive [[utility]] or value to them (i.e., the thalamo-cortical loop).<ref>Thaler, S. L. (2011, [http://www.apaonline.org/APAOnline/Publication_Info/Newsletters/APAOnline/Publications/Newsletters/HTML_Newsletters/Vol11N2Spring2012/Computers.aspx#Thaler "The Creativity Machine Paradigm: Withstanding the Argument from Consciousness"]</ref><ref>Thaler, S. L. (2013) [http://www.springerreference.com/docs/html/chapterdbid/358097.html "The Creativity Machine Paradigm, Encyclopedia of Creativity, Invention, Innovation, and Entrepreneurship"], (ed.) E.G. Carayannis, Springer Science+Business Media</ref> The exploitation of these false memories by other artificial neural networks forms the basis of inventive [[artificial intelligence]] systems currently utilized in [[product design]],<ref>Pickover, C. A. (2005). Sex, Drugs, Einstein, & Elves, SmartPublications, Petaluma, CA.</ref><ref>Plotkin, R. (2009). The Genie in the Machine: How Computer-Automated Inventing is Revolutionizing Law and Business, Stanford University Press</ref> materials discovery<ref>Thaler, S. L. (1998). Predicting ultra-hard binary compounds via cascaded auto- and hetero-associative neural networks, Journal of Alloys and Compounds, 279(1998), 47-59.</ref> and improvisational [[military robot]]s.<ref name="Hesman, T. 2004">Hesman, T. (2004). The Machine That Invents, St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Jan. 25, 2004.</ref> Compound, confabulatory systems of this kind<ref>Thaler, S. L. (1996). A Proposed Symbolism for Network-Implemented Discovery Processes, In Proceedings of the World Congress on Neural Networks, (WCNN’96), Lawrence Erlbaum, Mawah, NJ.</ref> have been used as [[sensemaking]] systems for [[military intelligence]] and planning,<ref name="Hesman, T. 2004"/> self-organizing control systems for robots and [[space vehicle]]s,<ref>Patrick, M. C., Stevenson-Chavis, K., Thaler, S. L. (2007). [http://imagination-engines.com/Media/NASA-MSFC.pdf "Demonstration of Self-Training Autonomous Neural Networks in Space Vehicle Docking Simulations"], Aerospace Conference, 2007, 3–10 March 2007 IEEE</ref> and [[entertainment]].<ref name="Hesman, T. 2004"/> The concept of such opportunistic confabulation grew out of experiments with artificial neural networks that simulated [[brain cell]] [[apoptosis]].<ref>Yam, P. (1995). As They Lay Dying, Scientific American, May 1995.</ref> It was discovered that novel perception, ideation, and [[motor planning]] could arise from either reversible or irreversible [[Neurobiology|neurobiological]] damage.<ref>Thaler, S. L. (1995). Death of a gedanken creature, Journal of Near-Death Studies, 13(3), Spring 1995.</ref><ref>Thaler, S. L. (2012). The Creativity Machine Paradigm: Withstanding the Argument from Consciousness, APA Newsletter, Volume 11, Number 2, Spring 2012.</ref>
==Computational inductive reasoning== The term confabulation is also used by [[Robert Hecht-Nielsen]] in describing [[inductive reasoning]] accomplished via [[Bayesian network]]s.<ref>Hecht-Nielsen, R (2005). [http://r.ucsd.edu/Cogent%20Confabulation.pdf "Cogent confabulation"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160114070727/http://r.ucsd.edu/Cogent%20Confabulation.pdf |date=2016-01-14 }}. Neural Networks 18:111-115.</ref> Confabulation is used to select the expectancy of the concept that follows a particular context. This is not an [[Aristotelianism|Aristotelian]] deductive process, although it yields simple [[Deductive reasoning|deduction]] when [[memory]] only holds unique events. However, most events and concepts occur in multiple, conflicting contexts and so confabulation yields a consensus of an expected event that may only be minimally more likely than many other events. <!--could you check/rewrite the following sentence?:-->However, given the winner take all constraint of the theory, that is the event/symbol/concept/attribute that is then expected. This parallel [[computation]] on many contexts is postulated to occur in less than a tenth of a second. Confabulation grew out of [[vector analysis]] of data retrieval like that of latent [[Semantic analysis (machine learning)|semantic analysis]] and [[support vector machine]]s. It is currently used to detect [[credit card fraud]].{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} It is being implemented computationally on parallel computers.

{{Infobox person | name = D.W. "James" Mooney | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = 1882 | death_place = | occupation = [[Prospecting|Prospector]] | spouse = | parents = | children = }} [[File:Mooney Falls, Arizona, 2006.jpg|thumb|Mooney Falls near Supai, AZ, which is where D.W. Mooney fell, now bears his name]] '''D. W. "James" Mooney''' (died 1882) was a miner and an early explorer of the [[Grand Canyon]]. He fell to his death at Mooney Falls, a waterfall on the [[Havasupai]] Reservation in the Grand Canyon. <!--THE FOLLOWING TEXT IS COPIED FROM THE SOURCED CITE, NEEDS A COMPLETE REWRITE '''D. W. "James" Mooney''' (d. [[1882]]) was a mining prospector and one of the early [[Grand Canyon]] explorers. He lost his life trying to find a route down into the canyon in the area that was named [[Havasupai#Mooney Falls|Mooney Falls]] after him. Along with Alphonso Humphreys, H. J. Young, W. C. Beckman, Mat Humphreys and W. W. Jones filed Cataract Canyon Mining Claims from the Department of Mineral Resources in Phoenix [[1879]]. The claim ran through [[1883]].
Tales of his death were apparently elaborated by G.W. James in ''In and About the Grand Canyon'', which tells of Mooney hanging suspended from a jammed rope for three days. There is apparently no evidence for this - in a letter, Alphonso Humphreys wrote:
{{cquote|I well remember the trip that Mooney fell. We had been down in the canyon about three days when Mooney fell and was killed, and we had no way to get down to bury his remains till eleven months and a day. The day Mooney fell we were all down in the canyon except Beckman, and when we returned to camp there was no levity amoung '''[sic]''' us. Beckman noticed that, and not seeing Mooney he asked about him, and Doheny told him he fell and was killed. The next morning before any of us was up he went down to the cliff to see if Mooney had moved. He untied the rope and tossed it down with his boots and said, this is all the funeral I can give you this time. Mooney, before starting down on his rope had pulled off his boots and asked me to lend him my belt which was a wide one. I have never seen the belt to this day, but Mooney's boots showed us the way to go down and bury him. We noticed the boots on an Indian. We asked him how he got the boots. To make a long story short, Young went with the Indian, who showed him the way he went down - a dangerous trip along a crevice in the wall of the canyon part of the way. Young wouldn't try that trail, but the Indian showed us some little caves, and we made the tunnel thru '''[sic]''' the cliff.}}-->
==References== *[http://home.znet.com/schester/grand_canyon/mooney.html Znet.com]
