revision.text:
The '''Legend of the Mistletoe Bough''' is a horror story which has been associated with many [[mansion]]s and [[stately home]]s in [[England]].
A new bride, playing a game of [[hide-and-seek]] during her [[wedding breakfast]], hides in a chest in an attic and is unable to escape. She is not discovered by her family and friends, and suffocates or dies of thirst. The body is found many years later in the locked chest as a skeleton in a wedding dress.
Notable claimants for the story's location, some still displaying the chest, include [[Bramshill House]] and [[Marwell Zoological Park|Marwell Hall]] in Hampshire, [[Castle Horneck]] in [[Cornwall]], [[Basildon]] Grotto in [[Berkshire]], [[Minster Lovell]] Hall in [[Oxfordshire]], [[Exton Hall]] in [[Rutland]], [[Brockdish]] Hall in [[Norfolk]] and [[Bawdrip]] Rectory in [[Somerset]].{{cn|date=August 2018}}
==History== The tale first appeared in print in the form of a poem by [[Samuel Rogers]] entitled Ginevra, in his book 'Italy' published in 1822.<ref>Samuel Rogers: ''Italy, A Poem'', Part the first. London 1822. [https://books.google.com/books?id=L7EDAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA123 pp. 123-130 books.google]</ref> In notes on this work, Rogers states ‘The story is, I believe, founded on fact; though the time and the place are uncertain. Many old houses lay claim to it.’<ref>Samuel Rogers: ''Italy, A Poem'', London 1830. [https://books.google.com/books?id=o9YQAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA259 p. 259 books.google].</ref> See also ''The Bride of Modena'' by [[John Heneage Jesse]], in: ''Tales of the Dead, and Other Poems'', London 1830, [https://books.google.com/books?id=IHKXwjnIYr0C&pg=PA35 pp. 35-59 books.google].
The popularity of the tale was greatly increased when it appeared as a song in the 1830s entitled 'The Mistletoe Bough' written by [[Thomas Haynes Bayley|T.H. Bayley]] and Sir [[Henry Bishop (composer)|Henry Bishop]]. The song proved very popular. In 1859, its 'solemn chanting' was referred to as a 'national occurrence at Christmas'<ref>{{cite web | first = | title = England and the English. Bentley's Miscellany Vol XLVI| publisher = Richard Bentley. 1859| url = https://www.google.com/books?id=NDsFAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA388&dq=chest+mistletoe+date:1830-18700&as_brr=1| accessdate = 2007-11-17 }}</ref> in English households, and by 1862 the song was referred to as 'one of the most popular songs ever written', 'which must be known by heart by many readers'.<ref>{{cite web | first = | title = Cache-cache. Notes and Queries| publisher = London, Bell and Daldy. August 30, 1862 | url = https://www.google.com/books?id=PZsgAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA176&dq=Legend+of+the+Mistletoe+Bough&as_brr=1#PPA177,M1| accessdate = 2007-11-17 }}</ref>
Further works inspired by the song include a play of the same name by Charles A Somerset first produced in 1835. A short story, 'Ginevra or The Old Oak Chest: A Christmas Story' by [[Susan Wallace|Susan E Wallace]] published in 1887 and another short story "The Romance of Certain Old Clothes" by [[Henry James]] published in 1868. The song is also played in [[Thomas Hardy]]'s ''A Laodicean'', after the scene involving the capture of George Somerset's handkerchief from the tower.
[[Kate Mosse]] reinterpreted the story in her 2013 short story collection ''The Mistletoe Bride and Other Haunting Tales''.<ref>{{cite book|first=Kate|last=Mosse|date=24 October 2013|title=The Mistletoe Bride and Other Haunting Tales|publisher=[[Orion Publishing Group]]|isbn=978-140-914806-7}}</ref>
Film versions of the story include a 1904 production by the [[Clarendon Film Company]], directed by [[Percy Stow]];<ref>{{cite web|title=The Mistletoe Bough|url=http://explore.bfi.org.uk/4ce2b6b4d4ccc|publisher=BFI|accessdate=2 October 2013}}</ref> a 1923 version made by the [[British and Colonial Kinematograph Company]];<ref>{{cite web|title=The Mistletoe Bough|url=http://explore.bfi.org.uk/4ce2b745e4f10|publisher=BFI|accessdate=2 October 2013}}</ref> and a 1926 production by Cosmopolitan Films, directed by [[C.C. Calvert]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Mistletoe Bough|url=http://explore.bfi.org.uk/4ce2b6bea0e66|publisher=BFI|accessdate=2 October 2013}}</ref>
The Percy Stow film version of the story can be seen on the BFI player with a new specially commissioned score by [[Pete Wiggs]] from the band [[Saint Etienne (band)|Saint Etienne]] <ref>{{cite web|url=https://player.bfi.org.uk/player/watch-the-mistletoe-bough-150051974/tmam00aTqGYHEkE-Wr12_M2hvHpNmwPX|title=Search|website=BFI Player}}</ref>
The story of the Mistletoe Bough is recounted in the 1948 [[Alfred Hitchcock]] film [[Rope (film)|''Rope'']], where it is described as being the favourite tale of the main character, Brandon Shaw. Unbeknownst to the story teller, the body of his murdered son had been hidden by Shaw in the chest in front of which they are standing.
{{wikisource|The Mistletoe Bough}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://books.google.com/books?id=dogvornHYEAC&pg=PA33&lpg=PA33&dq=ginevra+chest&source=web&ots=TG2RwFaz3b&sig=SYANGBWZkYlcjQbqizM6iAESkRo#PPA33,M1 Full text version of the Samuel Rogers poem] * [http://bodley24.bodley.ox.ac.uk/cgi-bin/acwwweng/ballads/image.pl?ref=Harding+B+16(151a)&id=06993.gif&seq=1&size=0 An early song sheet for 'The Mistletoe Bough']
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mistletoe}} [[Category:English folklore]] [[Category:Premature burials]] [[Category:Culture in Hampshire]]

revision.comment: removed unreliable source, Cawley is not an historian
revision.text:
{{Infobox noble|type | name = Leopold V the Virtuous | title = [[List of rulers of Austria|Duke of Austria]] | image = Herzog Leopold V. Babenberg.jpg | caption = Leopold receiving the banner from Emperor Henry VI, ''Babenberger Stammbaum'', [[Klosterneuburg Monastery]], 1489–1492 | alt = | CoA = | more = no | reign = 1177–1194 | reign-type = [[Duke]] | predecessor = [[Henry II, Duke of Austria|Henry II]] | successor = [[Frederick I, Duke of Austria (Babenberg)|Frederick I]] | suc-type = Successor | succession = | spouse = [[Helena of Hungary, Duchess of Austria|Helena of Hungary]] | spouse-type = Spouse | issue = [[Frederick I, Duke of Austria (Babenberg)|Frederick I, Duke of Austria]]
[[Leopold VI, Duke of Austria]] | issue-link = | issue-pipe = | full name = | styles = | titles = | noble family = [[House of Babenberg]] | house-type = Nobility | father = [[Henry II, Duke of Austria|Henry II]] | mother = [[Theodora Komnene (Austria)|Theodora Komnene]] | birth_date = 1157 | birth_place = Austria | christening_date = | christening_place = | death_date = {{death date|1194|12|31|df=y}} (aged 37) | death_place = [[Graz]], [[Duchy of Styria|Styria]] | burial_date = | burial_place = [[Heiligenkreuz Abbey]] | occupation = }} '''Leopold V''' (1157 – 31 December 1194), known as '''the Virtuous''' ({{lang-de|der Tugendhafte}}), a member of the [[House of Babenberg]], was [[List of rulers of Austria|Duke of Austria]] from 1177 and [[Duchy of Styria|Duke of Styria]] from 1192 until his death. ==Biography== Leopold was the son of the [[Duchy of Austria|Austrian]] duke [[Henry II, Duke of Austria|Henry II Jasomirgott]] from his second marriage with the [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] princess [[Theodora Komnene, Duchess of Austria|Theodora]], a daughter of [[Andronikos Komnenos (son of John II)|Andronikos Komnenos]], the second eldest son of Emperor [[John II Komnenos]].Lingelbach 1913, pp. 91–92. Just before his birth, his father had achieved the elevation of the [[Margraviate of Austria|Austrian margraviate]] to a duchy according to the 1156 ''[[Privilegium Minus]]'', issued by Emperor [[Frederick I, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick Barbarossa]]. As the eldest son of Henry II, Leopold was already enfeoffed with the Austrian duchy by the emperor in the summer of 1174 at [[Regensburg]]. He succeeded his father as Duke of Austria upon his death on 13 January 1177. Soon after, Leopold lent his support to Duke [[Frederick, Duke of Bohemia|Frederick of Bohemia]] stuck in a conflict with his [[Přemyslid dynasty|Přemyslid]] cousin [[Soběslav II, Duke of Bohemia|Soběslav II]], who had campaigned in the Austrian duchy. In turn, Leopold reached a peace agreement with the neighbouring [[Duchy of Bohemia]], determined by Emperor Frederick Barbarossa at [[Cheb|Eger]] in 1179. Two years later, he attended an [[Imperial Diet (Holy Roman Empire)|Imperial Diet]] in [[Erfurt]], where his first-born son [[Frederick I, Duke of Austria (Babenberg)|Frederick]] was enfeoffed with the Austrian estate. In 1182 Leopold went on a pilgrimage to the [[Holy Land]] and was received with honour at the courts of King [[Béla III of Hungary]] and of Emperor [[Alexios II Komnenos]] in [[Constantinople]]. Back in Germany, he began negotiating the [[Georgenberg Pact]] with the last [[Otakars|Otakar]] duke [[Ottokar IV, Duke of Styria|Ottokar IV of Styria]], who had received the ducal title from Emperor Frederick in 1180. The agreement was concluded on 17 August 1186, whereafter [[Duchy of Styria|Styria]] and the central part of [[Upper Austria]] with [[Wels]] and [[Steyr]] were amalgamated into the [[Duchy of Austria]] upon Ottokar's death in 1192. The next year Leopold was enfeoffed with Styria by the emperor; this was the first step towards the creation of modern [[Austria]]. Leopold is mainly remembered outside Austria for his participation in the [[Third Crusade]]. Border disputes with King Béla III of Hungary had initially impeded the duke from accompanying Emperor Frederick on his departure in May 1189. When he heard about the emperor's death in 1190, he went to [[Venice]], where he embarked to the Holy Land. Autumn storms forced him to winter in [[Zadar]] on the [[Adriatic Sea|Adriatic]] coast. He arrived in Palestine to take part in the final stage of the [[Siege of Acre (1189–1191)|Siege of Acre]] in spring 1191. Leopold assumed command of the remnants of the Imperial forces after the death of the emperor's son Duke [[Frederick VI, Duke of Swabia|Frederick of Swabia]] in January. According to legend, his tunic was blood-soaked after the fights. When he doffed his belt, a white stripe appeared. The new emperor [[Henry VI, Holy Roman Emperor|Henry VI]] granted him the privilege to adopt these colours as his new [[banner]], that later would become the [[flag of Austria]]. Acre surrendered on July 12, after the arrival of [[Philip II of France|King Philip II of France]] and [[Richard I of England|King Richard I of England]]. Duke Leopold, as commander of the German contingent, demanded rights equal to those of the two kings but was rejected. When the banners of the [[Kingdom of Jerusalem]], [[Kingdom of England|England]], [[Kingdom of France|France]] and Leopold's ducal flag were raised in the city by Leopold's cousin, Marquis [[Conrad of Montferrat]], Richard removed Leopold's colours (see [[Siege of Acre (1189–1191)|Siege of Acre]]) and the duke wrathfully left for his Austrian home, where he arrived by the end of 1191. In January 1192 he proceeded to the court of Emperor Henry VI and complained bitterly about Richard, who also was suspected of involvement in the murder of Conrad, shortly after his election as [[Kings of Jerusalem|King of Jerusalem]] in April. The emperor probably agreed with King Philip, already in conflict with the English king, on Richard's capture. When Richard left the Holy Land in late October 1192, he found the French ports closed and sailed up the Adriatic Sea. He took the country road from [[Aquileia]] across Austria, to reach the [[Duchy of Bavaria|Bavarian]] estates of his [[House of Welf|Welf]] brother-in-law [[Henry the Lion]]. Whilst travelling under disguise, he stopped at [[Vienna]] shortly before Christmas 1192, where he was recognized (supposedly because of his signet ring) and arrested in Erdberg (modern [[Landstraße]] district). Initially Duke Leopold had the king imprisoned in [[Dürnstein]], and in March 1193 Richard was brought before Emperor Henry VI at [[Trifels Castle]], accused of Conrad's murder. A ransom of 35,000 kilograms of silver was paid to release King Richard.{{cite book|author=Horst Fuhrmann|title=Germany in the High Middle Ages: C.1050-1200|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hlapxde55rAC&pg=PA182|date=9 October 1986|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-31980-5|page=182}} Leopold demanded that Richard's niece, [[Eleanor, Fair Maid of Brittany|Eleanor]], marry his son Frederick. Due to Leopold's death, this marriage never took place. Leopold's share of the ransom became the foundation for the mint in Vienna, and was used to build new [[city wall]]s for Vienna, as well as to found the towns of [[Wiener Neustadt]] and [[Friedberg, Styria|Friedberg]] in Styria. The duke was [[Excommunication|excommunicated]] by [[Pope Celestine III]] for having taken a fellow [[Crusades|crusader]] prisoner. To receive absolution, Leopold prepared for another crusade, but this plan failed. In 1194, his foot was crushed when [[List of horse accidents|his horse fell on him]] at a [[tournament (medieval)|tournament]] in [[Graz]]. Though advised by his surgeons to have the foot amputated, no one admitted to being able to do it. He ordered his servants to chop his foot off with an axe, which they succeeded in doing after three swings.Howden 1871, pp. 276-78. He succumbed to [[gangrene]]. As a result of deathbed promises to make restitution given to the hastily-summoned Archbishop [[Adalbert III of Bohemia|Adalbert of Salzburg]], he was reconciled and received a Christian burial at [[Heiligenkreuz Abbey]]. ==Marriage and children== At Pentecost 1174, Leopold married [[Helena of Hungary, Duchess of Austria|Helena]] (1158–1199), a daughter of late King [[Géza II of Hungary]]. By her, Leopold had at least two children: * [[Frederick I, Duke of Austria (Babenberg)|Frederick I]] ({{circa|1175}} – 1198),Fastlinger 1920, p. 112. who succeeded his father as Duke of Austria * [[Leopold VI, Duke of Austria|Leopold VI]] (1176–1230), succeeded his father as Duke of Styria (inconsistent with the Georgenberg Pact) and became Duke of Austria upon his brother's death in 1198. ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Leopold V, Duke of Austria''' |2= 2. [[Henry II, Duke of Austria]] |3= 3. [[Theodora Komnene (Austria)|Theodora Komnene]] |4= 4. [[Leopold III, Margrave of Austria]] |5= 5. [[Agnes of Germany]] |6= 6. [[Andronikos Komnenos (son of John II Komnenos)|Andronicus Comnenus]] |7= 7. Eirene (?Aineiadissa) |8= 8. [[Leopold II, Margrave of Austria]] |9= 9. [[Ida of Formbach-Ratelnberg]] |10= 10. [[Henry IV, Holy Roman Emperor]] |11= 11. [[Bertha of Savoy]] |12= 12. [[John II Komnenos|John II Comnenus]] |13= 13. [[Piroska of Hungary]] |16= 16. [[Ernest, Margrave of Austria|Ernest of Austria]] |17= 17. [[Adelaide of Eilenburg|Adelaide Von Eilenburg]] |18= 18. Rapoto IV of Cham |20= 20. [[Henry III, Holy Roman Emperor]] |21= 21. [[Agnes de Poitou]] |22= 22. [[Otto of Savoy]] |23= 23. [[Adelaide of Susa]] |24= 24. [[Alexios I Komnenos|Alexius I Comnenus]] |25= 25. [[Irene Doukaina]] |26= 26. [[Ladislaus I of Hungary]] |27= 27. [[Adelaide of Rheinfelden|Adelaide of Swabia]] }} ==See also== * [[List of rulers of Austria]] ==References== ;Citations {{reflist}} ;Bibliography {{refbegin}} * {{cite book|last=Beller |first=Steven |title=A Concise History of Austria |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=New York |year=2007 |isbn=978-0521478861}} * {{cite book|last=Brooke |first=Z. N. |title=A History of Europe: From 911 to 1198 |publisher=Methuen & Company Ltd |location=London |year=1938 |isbn=978-1443740708}} * {{cite book|last=Dopsch |first=Heinz |title=Österreichische Geschichte 1122-1278 |publisher=Ueberreuter |location=Vienna |year=1999 |isbn=3-8000-3973-7}} * {{cite book|last=Howden |first=Roger |editor=William Stubbs |title=Chronica (4 volumes)|year=1871 |isbn=}} * {{cite book|last=Lechner |first=Karl |title=Die Babenberger: Markgrafen und Herzoge von Österreich 976–1246 |publisher=Böhlau |location=Vienna |year=1976 |isbn=978-3205085089}} * {{cite book|last=Leeper |first=Alexander W. |title=History of Medieval Austria |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=London |year=1941 |isbn=978-0404153472}} * {{cite book|last=Lingelbach |first=William E. |title=The History of Nations: Austria-Hungary |publisher=P. F. Collier & Son Company |location=New York |year=1913 |isbn= |asin=B000L3E368}} * {{cite book|last=Pohl |first=Walter |title=Die Welt der Babenberger |publisher=Verlag Styria |location=Graz |year=1995 |isbn=978-3222123344}} * {{cite book|last=Rickett |first=Richard |title=A Brief Survey of Austrian History |publisher=Prachner |location=Vienna |year=1985 |isbn=978-3853670019}} * {{cite book|last=Wegener |first=Wilhelm |title=Genealogischen Tafeln zur mitteleuropäischen Geschichte |publisher=Verlag Degener |location=Vienna |year=1965 |isbn=}} {{refend}} ==External links== {{commons category|Leopold V, Duke of Austria}} * [http://www.aeiou.at/aeiou.encyclop.l/l521666.htm Leopold V., Herzog] at [http://www.aeiou.at/ AEIOU] {{Clear}} {{S-start}} {{s-hou|[[House of Babenberg]]||1157|31 December|1194}} {{s-roy|de}} {{s-bef|before=[[Henry II, Duke of Austria|Henry II]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[List of rulers of Austria|Duke of Austria]]|years=1177–1194}} {{s-aft|after=[[Frederick I, Duke of Austria (Babenberg)|Frederick I]]}} {{s-bef|before=[[Ottokar IV, Duke of Styria|Ottokar IV]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Styria (duchy)|Duke of Styria]]|years=1192–1194}} {{s-aft|after=[[Leopold VI, Duke of Austria|Leopold II]]}} {{s-end}} {{Clear}} {{Austria Rulers}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Leopold 05, Duke of Austria}} [[Category:1157 births|Leopold V of Austria (Babenberg)]] [[Category:1194 deaths|Leopold V of Austria (Babenberg)]] [[Category:12th-century rulers of Austria]] [[Category:12th-century Austrian people]] [[Category:Dukes of Austria|Leopold 5]] [[Category:Dukes of Styria|Leopold 5]] [[Category:Babenberg|Leopold 5]] [[Category:Christians of the Third Crusade]] [[Category:People temporarily excommunicated by the Roman Catholic Church|Leopold 5]] [[Category:Deaths by horse-riding accident]] [[Category:Deaths from gangrene]] [[Category:Burials at Heiligenkreuz Abbey]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=August 2013}} [[File:Living interfaith church web screenshot.png|380px|thumb|right|A screenshot from the Living Interfaith Church's website]]
'''Living Interfaith Church''' is a religious unity founded by Steven Greenebaum and based in [[Lynnwood, Washington]], United States, which embraces the teachings of all [[spirituality|spiritual]] paths that lead people to seek a life of compassionate action.<ref name=meetup>{{cite web| url=http://www.meetup.com/Living-Interfaith-Church/|title=Living Interfaith Church|work=[[Meetup (website)]]| accessdate=August 18, 2013}}</ref>
Interfaith, as a faith, does not seek to discover which religion or spiritual path is "right". Rather, it recognizes that everyone is brother and sister, and that at different times and different places we have encountered the [[sacred]] differently.<ref name=meetup/>
==General information== ===The religion=== Living Interfaith Church celebrates differing spiritual paths. They claim that what is the same in every [[religion]] is the call to compassion, the call to think beyond ourselves, and to recognize that we are all connected. Interfaith "calls upon us not to ignore our differences, but to rather to respect them, and to realize that each of our paths, in their own special and different way, call us to love and to be loving".<ref>{{cite news| url= http://livinginterfaith.org/?page_id=120|work=livinginterfaith.org|author=|title=Living Interfaith Church FAQ’s |date=| accessdate=August 20, 2013}}</ref>
The church views Interfaith as a faith that celebrates humanity's differing spiritual paths. It believes that a person's actions in this world are what count and that humanity is called to engage the world, both with compassion and with love. A stated tenet of the church is to respect all faith traditions and not to ignore their importance or their differences. [[Christianity]] is acknowledged as different from [[Buddhism]]. [[Islam]] is acknowledged as different from [[Humanism]], and so forth. According to the movement, the claim of Interfaith as a faith is that what is the same within all of humanity’s spiritual paths is the call to compassion, to thinking beyond ourselves, and to recognizing that we are all connected.<ref name="Living Interfaith Church FAQ">{{cite web | title=Living Interfaith Church FAQ’s | website=Living Interfaith Church | date=July 13, 2013 | url=http://www.livinginterfaith.org/living-interfaith-church-faqs/ | access-date=March 29, 2018}}</ref>
Greenebaum stated that "interfaith, as a spiritual practice, can serve as a new model for how we deal with each other and a new vision for how we act on our religious beliefs to live compassionate lives and share the world in harmony."<ref name=journal>{{cite journal|last=Swift|first=Diana|title=Why Faith is Better Than Religion|journal=Anglican Journal|date=December 3, 2013}}</ref>
===The founder=== Reverend Steven Greenebaum, the founder of the Living Interfaith Church, grew up as a [[Reform Jew]] in suburban [[Los Angeles]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/13/us/a-religion-that-embraces-all-religions.html?_r=1& |work=|author= Samuel G. Freedman|title=A Church That Embraces All Religions and Rejects ‘Us’ vs. ‘Them’| date=July 12, 2013}}</ref>
He has a [[Master's degree]] in [[Mythology]], [[Music]], and [[Pastoral]] Studies. His experiences directing [[Jewish]], [[Methodist]], [[Presbyterian]], and [[Interfaith]] choirs have helped him to understand the profound wisdom of many spiritual traditions. He has dedicated his life to working for social and environmental justice through a multitude of forums.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.newsociety.com/Contributors/G/Greenebaum-Reverend-Steven|work=|author=|title= Reverend Steven Greenebaum | date=| accessdate=August 20, 2013}}</ref> When asked about his entity, he explained: “My faith is Interfaith. My spiritual path is Judaism. My tribe is Humanity. I’m also a minister, choir director, and vegetarian.”<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.meetup.com/Living-Interfaith-Church/members/13440755/ |work=|author=|title=Rev. Steven Greenebaum| date=| accessdate=August 20, 2013}}</ref><ref name=journal/>
In 2012 he published his first book [https://www.amazon.com/The-Interfaith-Alternative-Embracing-Spiritual/dp/0865717052/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1377031846&sr=8-1&keywords=the+interfaith+alternative ''The Interfaith Alternative: Embracing Spiritual Diversity''] through [[New Society Publishers]].<ref>{{cite news| url= http://livinginterfaith.org/?page_id=125|work=|author=|title= Meet Reverend Steven Greenebaum| date=| accessdate=August 20, 2013}}</ref> His second book, [https://www.amazon.com/Practical-Interfaith-Humanity-Celebrate-Diversity/dp/1594735697/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1467067037&sr=8-1&keywords=practical+interfaith''Practical Interfaith''], was published by [http://www.skylightpaths.com/ ''Skylight Paths''] in 2014.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.livinginterfaith.org Official website]
[[Category:Interfaith organizations]] [[Category:Religious faiths, traditions, and movements]] [[Category:Religious organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Spirituality]]

'''Elizabeth Stride''' (August 31, 1877 - 1919), known professionally as '''Lizzie Arlington''', was an [[United States|American]] [[baseball]] player. She was the first woman to play for a professional men's baseball team.
==Early life== Arlington was the youngest of six children born to English emigrants Henry and Mary Stride. She grew up in [[Mahanoy City, Pennsylvania]], where she played baseball with her father and brothers.<ref name=Bloomers>{{cite book|last1=Shattuck|first1=Debra|title=Bloomer Girls: Women Baseball Pioneers|date=2017|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0-252-08186-6|page=149}}</ref>
On June 20, 1891, at age 13, Arlington took the field as the pitcher for the Mahanoy City baseball team against the visiting Cincinnati Reds (a professional women's team barnstorming through the area). Reds' manager Mark Lally, impressed with her play, immediately recruited and signed her to play for his team. Arlington played three seasons with the Reds, including two where she shared pitching duties with [[Maud Nelson]].<ref name=Bloomers />
Arlington played for the [[Young Ladies Baseball Club of New York]] in 1894 and the other [[Young Ladies Baseball Club of New York]] (also known as the New York Stars) in 1895.<ref name=Bloomers />
==Minor League Baseball (1898)== In 1898, sporting and theatrical promoter William J. Connor engaged Arlington for $100.00 a week and negotiated with [[Atlantic League (1896–1900)|Atlantic League]] president [[Ed Barrow|Edward G. Barrow]] for her to sign a minor league contract. She debuted later that year while pitching for the reserve team of the Philadelphia Nationals, and continued to pitch and play [[infield]] against several professional clubs in exhibition games around the country throughout the summer.<ref name=TPG>{{cite book |last1=Seymour |first1=Harold |last2=Seymour |first2=Dorothy Z. |title=Baseball: The People's Game |date=1991 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-506907-5}}</ref><ref>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/yearly/yr1898n.shtml Baseball Almanac – 1898 in review]</ref>
On July 5, 1898, Arlington became the first woman to play for a professional men's baseball team when she pitched the ninth inning for the [[Reading Phillies|Reading Coal Heavers]] against the [[Allentown Peanuts]]. Reading was leading 5-0 heading into the final inning when Arlington entered the game. Though she allowed two [[hit (baseball)|hits]] and [[base on balls|walked]] a batter to [[Bases loaded|load the bases]], Arlington succeeded in retiring the next three batters to preserve the victory, as the crowd enthusiastically shouted "Good for Lizzie!"<ref name=Bloomers /><ref name=TPG />
The ''[[Reading Eagle]]'' newspaper reported that more than a thousand fans, including 200 women, attended the game to see what Arlington looked like and what she wore. She entered the grounds in a "stylish carriage drawn by two white horses" and, responding to applause by lifting her cap, revealed her hair done in the latest fashion. She wore black stockings and a gray uniform with knee-length skirt. During the pre-game practice, Arlington played [[second base]] like a professional, "even down to expectorating on her hands and wiping them on her uniform", according to the report.<ref name=TPG />
The verdict of the ''Eagle'''s sports writer was that Arlington might do all right among amateurs but lacked control and the strength to get much speed in the ball. However, he added, "for a woman, she is a success." A writer for the ''[[Hartford Courant]]'', anticipating her coming to play for the locals against the Newark team, commented, "It is said that she plays ball like a man and talks ball like a man and if it was not for her bloomers she would be taken for a man on the diamond, having none of the peculiarities of women ball players." But authorities cancelled the appearance of Arlington in Hartford, reportedly because the home team management wanted to take no chances on losing the game, and thereafter her name disappeared from the sports pages.<ref name=TPG />
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Arlington, Lizzie}} [[Category:Baseball pitchers]] [[Category:Baseball players from Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Female baseball players]] [[Category:Minor league baseball players]] [[Category:Date of death unknown]] [[Category:Place of death unknown]] [[Category:American sportswomen]] [[Category:1877 births]]

{{Infobox criminal | name = Marcus Schrenker | image_name = | image_size = | image_caption = | birth_place = ~ {{birth year and age|1971}} | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | alias = | motive = | charge = Illegal destruction of an aircraft, deceiving the [[United States Coast Guard|Coast Guard]] (federal), [[securities fraud]], operating as an investment banker without being registered (state)Laurence Viele Davidson for Bloomberg News. January 21, 2009 [https://web.archive.org/web/20140227143007/http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aIeMZ02ICeeo&refer=home Indiana Fund Manager Indicted for Faking His Death (Update2)]. | conviction = June 5, 2009 (federal, pleaded guilty)
October 7, 2010 (state, pleaded guilty) | conviction_penalty = 51 months in prison and $905,000 fine (federal)
10 years in prison (consecutive) and fines of $633,781 (state) | conviction_status = | occupation = [[Financial advisor]] | spouse = Michelle Schrenker (divorced) | parents = | children = 3 }} '''Marcus Schrenker''' (born ~1971) is a former [[financial advisor]] from [[Indiana]]. He is best known for attempting to [[Pseudocide|fake his own death]] due to personal, financial, and legal trouble and for the multi-state, three-day [[Manhunt (law enforcement)|manhunt]] that followed in January 2009.Jay Reeves and Rick Callahan for the Associated Press, via Yahoo news. Jan 13, 2009. [https://web.archive.org/web/20090119140636/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090113/ap_on_bi_ge/plane_crash_mystery "Investors Complained About Missing Ind. Pilot]Brooke Baldwin, Kevin Bohn, Kathleen Johnston and Tristan Smith for CNN. January 14, 2009 [http://www.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/01/14/missing.pilot.found/ Affidavit: Fugitive pilot seemed ready to stay on run] His first wife Michelle divorced him, and after pleading guilty to federal charges he was sentenced to 51 months in prison and fined $905,000 in June 2009. In October 2010, after pleading guilty to state charges, he was sentenced to 10 years in prison (consecutive with the 51 months) and was fined $633,781 ==Background== Schrenker grew up in [[Merrillville, Indiana]] and attended [[Purdue University]], where he was a cheerleader and met his wife. Prior to January 2009, Schrenker lived with his wife and three children in a $1M waterfront house in [[Geist, Indianapolis|Geist]], a wealthy suburb of [[Indianapolis]]. and he owned a plane and a Lexus.{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Dirk|title=A Man With Everything, Including a Lot to Flee|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/15/us/15plane.html|work=The New York Times|date=2009}} Schrenker was listed as the owner of three companies, Heritage Wealth Management Inc. (HWM) and Icon Wealth Management, which had the same address, as well as Heritage Insurance Services, which was also at the same address.Josh Levs for CNN. January 12, 2009 [http://www.cnn.com/2009/US/01/12/florida.plane.crash/index.html Authorities: Pilot who bailed from plane under securities probe]. In December 2008 Schrenker and HWM was sued by another company that was trying to get back $1.4 million for commissions it had paid to Schrenker for selling insurance and annuity policies. On December 30 his wife filed for divorce because he had been having an affair with a woman at the airport where he kept his plane.Michael Pressman and Deborah Roberts for ABC News 20/20. March 26, 2010 [http://abcnews.go.com/2020/marcus-schrenker-fake-death/story?id=10201960 Marcus Schrenker's Life Spirals Out of Control]Note: Another source says the divorce was filed December 31: Jeff Swiatek for the Indianapolis Star. January 14, 2009 [https://web.archive.org/web/20090122213224/http://www.indystar.com/article/20090114/NEWS02/901140388/1003/BUSINESS Fishers businessman cut his wrist, officials say]. The next day, his Indiana state financial advisor license expired,Staff, Fox News. January 14, 2009 [http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,479883,00.html Timeline: Marcus Schrenker Plane Hoax Mystery]". all three of his companies were searched under a warrant related to ongoing investigations, At the beginning of January, the Indiana Department of Insurance had filed a motion to revoke the license of Schrenker and Heritage and fine them, "citing a string of complaints from clients, some charging that he forged signatures and withdrew investment money causing large surrender penalties." And on January 9, Schrenker had been ordered by a Maryland court to pay a Maryland insurance company $533,564 for issues also related to commissions.Tallahassee Democrat and wire reports via Staff, Pensacola News Journal. January 14, 2009 [https://web.archive.org/web/20090124092628/http://www.pnj.com/article/20090114/NEWS01/90114012 It's normally real quiet]". Schrenker was also being investigated by the FBI at the time the events occurred. In all, at least eight lawsuits had been filed against Schrenker in the ten years leading up to the events of January 2009, including [[slander]], interfering with a business relationship, and failing to pay a [[General contractor|contractor]] who worked on one of his homes.Jeff Swiatek for the Indianapolis Star. January 14, 2009 [https://web.archive.org/web/20090122213224/http://www.indystar.com/article/20090114/NEWS02/901140388/1003/BUSINESS Fishers businessman cut his wrist, officials say]. ==Plane crash and manhunt== On Saturday, January 10, 2009, Schrenker traveled to [[Harpersville, Alabama]], in a pickup truck carrying a red [[Yamaha Motor Company|Yamaha]] motorcycle with [[saddlebags]] containing money and supplies.Jessica Gresko and Jay Reeves for the Associated Press. Jan 14, 2009 [https://web.archive.org/web/20090122215846/http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hsET3AfuAoTChx5t6o2BcA9_YMbgD95MU4M02 Agent: Investor mutters "die" as run from law ends] He returned to Indiana after placing the motorcycle in a storage facility, telling the owner he would return and retrieve the motorcycle the following Monday. On January 11, 2009, Schrenker departed in his turboprop single-engine [[Piper Meridian]] (tail number N428DC) from an [[airfield]] in [[Anderson, Indiana]], scheduled to fly to [[Destin, Florida|Destin]], [[Florida]].Davin Coburn for Popular Mechanics. January 14, 2009 [https://web.archive.org/web/20090120163314/http://www.popularmechanics.com/science/worst_case_scenarios/4269526.html Marcus Schrenker's Fall From Grace: How this Financial Adviser (Almost) Pulled off a Daring Getaway] Near [[Birmingham, Alabama]], he made a distress call, telling [[air traffic controller]]s that his windshield had imploded and he was "bleeding profusely."Jeff Swiatek for The Indianapolis Star. January 12, 2009 [https://web.archive.org/web/20090123075200/http://www.indy.com/posts/indy-plane-crashes-in-fla-pilot-missing Fishers pilot vanishes over Alabama].Paul Lewis and agencies for The Guardian. January 14, 2009 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jan/15/businessman-faked-death-us Businessman faked death by jumping from plane]. He then set the plane to [[autopilot]] and parachuted out. Military jets that had been dispatched to intercept Schrenker's plane discovered it in flight, with its door open and cockpit empty. They followed the plane until it crashed just north of [[Milton, Florida]] at about 9:20pm.Tallahassee Democrat staff and wire reports. January 14, 2009 [https://web.archive.org/web/20090123065507/http://www.tallahassee.com/article/20090114/NEWS01/901140344/1010 Updated: Indiana fugitive facing federal charges in connection with plane crash] The plane had flown {{convert|200|mi|km}} on [[autopilot]] and crashed 50 to 75 yards from a residential area. Upon inspecting the crash site, investigators discovered that there was no blood inside the plane and the windshield showed no sign of problem. On board the aircraft they found a [[atlas|United States atlas]] and a national [[campground]] directory, both of which had the Florida and Alabama sections torn out.MSNBC news services Jan 15, 2009 [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/28623108/ Cockpit items led cops to missing financier]." After parachuting to the ground, Schrenker made his way to a private residence in [[Childersburg, Alabama]], arriving around 2:30am on January 12. Appearing wet from the knees down, he told the resident he had been in a [[canoe]]ing accident. He received a ride into town, where he made contact with the local police station. Not yet linking Schrenker to the crash, the police brought him to a hotel in [[Harpersville, Alabama|Harpersville]], where he checked in under a false name and paid for his room with cash. When police returned later that morning, he had fled on foot into nearby woods. Schrenker then traveled to the storage facility where he had earlier stored his motorcycle,Richard Luscombe in Miami for The Scotsman. January 14, 2009 [https://web.archive.org/web/20090122220131/http://news.scotsman.com/latestnews/Financier-fakes-down-death-in.4872042.jp Financier fakes down death in air crash before fleeing]". and then rode the vehicle to a [[Kampgrounds of America|KOA Campground]] in [[Quincy, Florida]].Sarah Netter for ABC News. Jan. 14, 2009 [http://abcnews.go.com/US/Story?id=6630842&page=2 New Charges for Pilot Suspected of Faking Death]". Without offering his name, he told the owners of the grounds that he was traveling cross country with friends, using cash to purchase a one-night tent site, firewood, and a six pack of [[Bud Light Lime]]. He was also given access to the campground's [[wireless internet]]. On January 12, Schrenker emailed neighbor and friend Tom Britt, stating the crash was "a misunderstanding" and that he had checked into the motel because he was "embarrassed and scared" of returning home.[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,479886,00.html Full Text of Marcus Schrenker's E-Mail to Neighbor] at [[Fox News Channel|Fox News]] He also said that he would likely "be gone" by the time Britt read the email.Chris Proffitt for Eyewitness News via MSNBC Jan. 13, 2009 [https://web.archive.org/web/20090122204239/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/28625061/ Search continues for missing Geist pilot]". Britt turned the email over to the police. The same day, a Hamilton County Superior Court judge froze the assets of both Schrenker and his estranged wife.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/US/01/13/pilot.assets/index.html|title=Judge freezes assets of pilot whose plane crashed without him|date=2009-01-13|publisher=CNN|accessdate=2009-01-13}} ==Capture== At about 10pm on January 13, officials captured Schrenker in a [[tent|pup tent]] at the Quincy campground; they had roughly located him using information from the email he had sent.ABC's Jeremy Hubbard via NECN. January 14, 2009 [https://web.archive.org/web/20090122210156/http://www.necn.com/Boston/Nation/2009/01/14/Missing-pilot-Schrenker-found/1231930621.htmll Missing pilot Schrenker found with slit wrist] The ground's owners, Troy and Caroline Hastings, grew suspicious when the man had failed to check out by 5pm. Upon approaching Schrenker's site, Troy Hasting noticed a large red stain on the outer flap of his tent. The couple were soon contacted by the local sheriff, who asked if anything unusual had happened recently at the camp. Mr. Hastings told the officer about the suspicious camper; shortly thereafter, authorities swarmed the campground. Investigators told the press that he had slashed his left wrist, had an additional self-inflicted wound near his elbow, and was barely conscious. [[US Marshal]] Assistant Chief Deputy Frank Chiumento said that Schrenker "wasn’t able to speak very clearly. A lot of the words that he was speaking were unintelligible, but he mentioned 'die' at least two times as we were providing medical treatment to him." He was in a "very incoherent state" and had lost massive amounts of blood by the time authorities first arrived, but paramedics were able to control his bleeding and he was [[Life flight (disambiguation)|Life-Flighted]] to [[Tallahassee Memorial Hospital]]. Among the items found at the campground with him were knives, a [[laptop computer]], toiletries, clothes and maps. ==Charges and trials== On January 13, 2009, Schrenker was charged in [[Hamilton County, Indiana]] with 11 counts of unlawful acts by a compensated adviser and unlawful transaction by an investment adviser, and his [[bail]] was set at $4 million. In May 2009 an Alabama judge granted a $12 million judgment against Schrenker related to the sale of an airplane to a man from Alabama.Bowdeya Tweh for The Times of Northwest Indiana. Aug 14, 2010 [https://web.archive.org/web/20160530052905/http://www.nwitimes.com/news/local/schrenker-appears-not-to-have-enough-funds-to-pay-claims/article_964437e1-d44c-5e14-88dc-88798b77b183.html Schrenker appears not to have enough funds to pay claims] In June 2009 Schrenker pleaded guilty to federal charges of destroying an aircraft and causing the U.S. Coast Guard to respond when no help was needed. In August he was sentenced to four years and three months in prison and was required to pay $34,000 in restitution to the Coast Guard and $871,000 in restitution to [[Harley-Davidson]], the plane's lien-holder.Staff, CNN. August 19, 2009 [http://www.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/08/19/fugitive.pilot/ Man gets 4 years for crashing plane, trying to fake death] By August 2010, his possessions had been sold off and there were civil claims against him totaling about $20M. In August 2010 he reached a deal with Indiana prosecutors to plead guilty to five counts of securities fraud, serve 10 years in prison and pay victims of his schemes more than $630,000, and in October the judgement was entered, with the 10 years' imprisonment ordered to run consecutively with the sentence on the federal charges for the faked plane crash.Staff, RTV6/ABC. October 8, 2010 [http://www.theindychannel.com/news/schrenker-sentenced-to-10-years-in-prison Schrenker Sentenced To 10 Years In Prison] A hearing on his ongoing divorce was scheduled for later that October. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Schrenker, Marcus}} [[Category:People from Hancock County, Indiana]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:People who faked their own death]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1970 births]]

{{unreferenced|date=December 2011}} {{other uses}} {{Quote box |title=Mental Cases |fontsize=100% |quote=<poem> Who are these? Why sit they here in twilight? Wherefore rock they, purgatorial shadows, Drooping tongues from jaws that slob their relish, Baring teeth that leer like skulls' tongues wicked? Stroke on stroke of pain, — but what slow panic, Gouged these chasms round their fretted sockets? Ever from their hair and through their hand palms Misery swelters. Surely we have perished Sleeping, and walk hell; but who these hellish?
— These are men whose minds the Dead have ravished. Memory fingers in their hair of murders, Multitudinous murders they once witnessed. Wading sloughs of flesh these helpless wander, Treading blood from lungs that had loved laughter. Always they must see these things and hear them, Batter of guns and shatter of flying muscles, Carnage incomparable and human squander Rucked too thick for these men's extrication.
Therefore still their eyeballs shrink tormented Back into their brains, because on their sense Sunlight seems a bloodsmear; night comes blood-black; Dawn breaks open like a wound that bleeds afresh — Thus their heads wear this hilarious, hideous, Awful falseness of set-smiling corpses. — Thus their hands are plucking at each other; Picking at the rope-knouts of their scourging; Snatching after us who smote them, brother, Pawing us who dealt them war and madness.
</poem>}} "'''Mental Cases'''" is one of [[Wilfred Owen]]'s more disturbing poems. It describes war-torn men suffering from [[post-traumatic stress disorder]], otherwise known as [[shell shock]]. Owen based the poem on his experience of [[Craiglockhart|Craiglockhart Military Hospital]], near Edinburgh, where he was invalided in the summer of 1917 with [[neurasthenia]], and became the patient of [[Dr A.J. Brock]]. Using imagery of death and violence, Owen presents a chilling portrait of men haunted by their experiences.
== Short Analysis ==
:The poem adopts a questioning tone initially, with the speaker asking “Who are these? Why sit they here in twilight?” Owen uses this to present the men almost as strange [[Freak show|carnival exhibits]] to be inspected or wondered at, emphasised by the base pronoun "these". They are depicted as grizzly, fascinating creatures, which seem "hellish" to the speaker. :The second stanza goes on to depict memory as a cruel monster which tortures their minds, forcing them to relive the "Carnage incomparable" they witnessed. Owen's chilling contrast between "Treading blood" and "lungs that had loved laughter" echoes a regular theme in his works, that the men who gave themselves for the war had once been amiable and friendly people before the dead "ravished" their minds. :The third stanza describes how those who survived the war live now with shell shock, in that scenes from the battlefield insert themselves into everyday life; sunlight is a "blood-smear" on a window, then night falls "blood-black" - they cannot escape the sight of blood. The macabre tone of the poem is added to by the image of hallucinations of "set-smiling corpses", describing the "hilarious, hideous" faces of the patients as they remember. Typically for Owen, he concludes with blame; it was "us who smote them", and "dealt them war and madness"; this echoes the ending of Owen's most famous poem, ''[[Dulce et Decorum est|Dulce et Decorum Est]]''. :{{Clear right}}
== References == {{Reflist}} {{wikisource}} {{Wilfred Owen}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mental Cases}} [[Category:British poetry]] [[Category:World War I poems]] [[Category:1918 poems]] [[Category:Poetry by Wilfred Owen]] [[Category:Posttraumatic stress disorder]]

{{Multiple issues| {{peacock|date=May 2009}} {{cleanup|date=March 2009}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox Information appliance |name = Nabaztag/tag |image = [[File:Nabaztag-IMG 1666.jpg|250px]] |caption = Nabaztag |developer = Violet |manufacturer = |type = Information console
[[Portable media player]] (PMP) |service = weather forecast
stock market report
news headlines
alarm clock
e-mail alerts
RSS-Feeds
MP3-Streams |lifespan = |unitssold = |cpu = PIC18F6525 }} [[File:Nabazmobny1.jpg|thumb|The 100 Rabbit Opera at the 2006 NextFest in New York]] '''Nabaztag''' ([[Armenian language|Armenian]] for "hare", [[:wikt:նապաստակ|նապաստակ]] (''napastak'')) is a [[Wi-Fi]] enabled [[ambient device|ambient electronic device]] in the shape of a rabbit, invented by [[Rafi Haladjian]] and [[Olivier Mével]], and manufactured by the company Violet.{{cite web |url=http://www.violet.net/index_en.html |title=Violet |website=violet.net |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100209071003/http://www.violet.net/index_en.html |archivedate=9 February 2010}} Nabaztag was designed to be a "smart object" comparable to those manufactured by [[Ambient Devices]]; it can connect to the [[Internet]] (to download weather forecasts, read its owner's email, etc.). It is also customizable and programmable to an extent. [[Sylvain Huet]]{{cite web |url=http://www.sylvain-huet.com/ |title=Sylvain Huet |website=www.sylvain-huet.com}} developed most of the embedded code of all Violet objects. [[Sebastien Bourdeauducq]] developed the [[Wi-Fi]] driver.{{cite web |url=http://lekernel.net/rt2571w.html |title=RT2501U/RT2571W Wi-Fi driver for ultra-embedded devices |website=lekernel.net |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110509020710/http://lekernel.net/rt2571w.html |archivedate=9 May 2011}} Antoine Schmitt{{cite web |url=http://www.gratin.org/as |title=Antoine Schmitt |website=gratin.org}} has been their behavior designer and [[Jean-Jacques Birgé]] their sound designer (together they have also composed ''Nabaz'mob'', an opera for 100 Nabaztag{{cite web |url=http://www.nabazmob.com |title=Nabaz'mob |website=nabazmob.com}}). Maÿlis Puyfaucher (who features its French voice) wrote all the original texts pronounced by the rabbit. On 20 October 2009, following a long period of technical difficulties that ultimately led to Violet's bankruptcy, [[Mindscape (software publisher)|Mindscape]] purchased Violet.{{cite web |url=http://www.neteco.com/306496-mindscape-officiellement-violet-Nabaztag.html |title=Mindscape rachète officiellement Violet et son Nabaztag |publisher=Neteco.com |date=21 October 2009 |accessdate=11 May 2011 |language=French}} In October 2010, [[Mindscape (software publisher)|Mindscape]] announced a third generation Nabaztag, called "Karotz".{{cite web |url=https://www.engadget.com/2010/10/15/mindscapes-karotz-continues-the-proud-Nabaztag-lineage |title=MindScape's Karotz continues the proud Nabaztag lineage |website=Engadget.com |date=15 October 2010 |accessdate=11 May 2011}} Karotz was released April 2012. On 27 July 2011, Mindscape stopped the maintenance of the Nabaztag and released its source code.{{cite web |url=http://www.01net.com/editorial/536566/Nabaztag-le-lapin-est-mort-ce-soir/ |title=Nabaztag, le lapin est mort ce soir |trans-title=The rabbit Nabaztag died tonight |website=01net.com |date=27 July 2011 |accessdate=27 July 2011 |language=French}} On 23 December 2011, it was announced that the Nabaztag rabbits would be "coming back to life" on 24 December 2011 at midnight via email to those with Violet accounts. The required server service at Nabaztag.com has since stopped functioning, but other options exist including setting up a server using OpenNab software or installing NabaztagLives on a [[Raspberry Pi]] single-board computer. ==Features== Out of the box, the Nabaztag rabbit is {{Convert|23|cm|abbr=on}} in height and weighs {{Convert|418|g|abbr=on}}. It can send and receive MP3s and messages that are read out loud as well as perform the following services (by either speaking the information out loud or using indicative lights): weather forecast, stock market report, news headlines, alarm clock, e-mail alerts, RSS-Feeds, MP3-Streams and others. There is an [[Application programming interface|API]], with bindings for multiple [[programming language]]s including [[Java (programming language)|Java]], [[Perl]], [[Python (programming language)|Python]],{{cite web |first1=Mike |last1=McGurrin |first2=Gena |last2=Cadieux |url=http://www.mcgurrin.com/Nabaztag/index.htm |title=Mike's Nabaztag Page |website=Mcgurrin.com |date=14 November 2009 |accessdate=11 May 2011}} or [[PHP]],{{cite web |author=caa |url=http://www.labo-caa.fr/Commander-Nabaztag-en-php.html |title=The PHP/Nab homepage |website=Labo-caa.fr |date= |accessdate=11 May 2011}} available to program the Nabaztag.{{cite web |first=Jean-Gregoire |last=Foulon |url=http://nabaztools.sourceforge.net/index.html |title=The Nabaztools homepage |website=Sourceforge.net |date=13 March 2006 |accessdate=11 May 2011}} At first speaking only in [[English language|English]] and [[French language|French]], as of June 2007, Nabaztag fully supports services in [[German language|German]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Dutch language|Dutch]]. The rabbits can be customized with Skinz tattoos, detachable USB tails in various colors, and many interchangeable ears with different designs and colors. The Nabaztag:tag and Karotz versions are capable of reading RFID chips, and products containing RFID chips include the Flatanoz key ring tags, miniature models of the rabbits called Nano:ztag, and some children's books. Individual RFID chips were also produced and were called ztamp:s.{{Cite web |first=Richard |last=MacManus |work=Mobiledia |url=http://readwrite.com/2009/05/24/mirror_rfid_glimpse |title=Mir:ror: A Glimpse Into The Future of an RFID World |date=May 24, 2009 |accessdate=March 11, 2015}} ==Community== Nabaztag owners can join [[social network]]s to [[photo sharing|share photos]] and videos on websites like [[Flickr]] and [[YouTube]]. Users can create [[podcasts]] (dubbed "Nabcasts" by Violet). There are currently over 100 of these available, mostly in English and French, created by different users on a variety of topics. Since Nabaztags can be programmed to provide new services using the API, there are user-created applications available, including a [[Dashboard (Mac OS)|Dashboard widget]] and a lottery alarm.{{Citation needed|date=March 2012}} ==Infrastructure shortcomings== In December 2006 (most notably around Christmas) a number of sold rabbits caused issues for Violet, the maker of Nabaztag. The Nabaztag device acts as a client to the France-based servers. When users attempted to register their new devices, the centralized servers were unable to handle the demand, resulting in service disruptions,{{cite web |url=http://blog.nabaztag.com/2006/12/paris_tuesday_d.html |date=26 December 2006 |title=Violet press release - Nabaztag's platform has buckled under the weight of all the new Rabbits! |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070104232121/http://blog.nabaztag.com/2006/12/paris_tuesday_d.html |archivedate=4 January 2007}} server unavailability, and data integrity problems caused by users creating multiple half-finished registrations. This resulted in a major customer service problem for Violet. The fundamental philosophy of Nabaztag, that all objects should be connected together on the Internet by a server maintained by Violet did not work as expected (e.g. the server sometimes could not cope with volume of traffic, services had to be switched off and there were unreliable response times often as slow as hours rather than seconds). In March 2008, Violet changed their server infrastructure and bunny software to use the standard [[Extensible Messaging and Presence Protocol|XMPP]] protocol. Bunnies were thereafter reacting much more rapidly on average, although long delays still occurred sometimes. The change caused service disruptions and problems for a couple of weeks.{{Citation needed|date=March 2012}} ==Technical specifications== The device embeds a [[PIC microcontroller|PIC18F6525 microcontroller]], a [[BenQ]] [[PC card]] 802.11b Wi-Fi adapter, an ml2870a Audio-PCM [[sound generator]], an [[ADPCM]] converter, two motors to activate the ears, a TLC5922 [[LED]] controller, and a small amount of [[RAM|memory]]. The embedded software handles the [[TCP/IP]] stack and Wi-Fi driver. It also implements a [[virtual machine]] which is able to execute up to 64 kb of code. A dedicated [[assembly language]] exists to program the different features of the device. ==Nabaztag/tag== Out on market on 12 December 2006, Nabaztag/tag is an improved model of Violet's Nabaztag. The new model supports [[MP3]] audio streaming for Internet radio (with preset radio stations and an app allowing to add your own stream that does not work) and podcasts. This second version Nabaztag has also added a microphone that allows for voice activation of some of its services. However, despite text on the website claiming that new services will be available soon, the number of working voice activated services remains less than a handful. A final added feature is a built-in RFID reader to detect special-purpose [[RFID]] tags (i.e. [[ISO/IEC 14443]] Type B). Nabaztag advertisement is presenting the ability to identify objects (depicted are e.g. keys). Nabaztag/tag can, as of November 2007, use RFID tags to read special edition versions of children's books by the French publisher [http://www.gallimard-jeunesse.fr/ Gallimard Jeunesse].{{Cite web |url=http://store.Nabaztag.com/eu/product_info.php?cPath=23&products_id=64&osCsid=cb9a8b084fcb9f4111c784b86278946d |title=Online store description |website=Nabaztag.com}} In October 2008, Violet launched RFID Children's Books with Penguin Publishing House.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/scienceandtechnology/technology/technologyreviews/3490743/Gadget-reviews.html?image=2 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |title=Gadget reviews |accessdate=19 May 2010 |date=20 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427091820/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/scienceandtechnology/technology/technologyreviews/3490743/Gadget-reviews.html?image=2 |archivedate=27 April 2009}} Further RFID services and support have been promised.{{cite web |url=http://www.Nabaztag.com/fr/m-21-Nabaztag-tag-le-second-premier-lapin-communicant.html |title=The "smell" feature demoed at the Nabaztag website |website=Nabaztag.com}} Violet has now started selling the Zstamps and Nano:ztags (little mini Rabbits with Zstamps inside them) and another called [[mir:ror]] which is its own RFID system separate from the Nabaztag. The Wi-Fi was also upgraded to support [[Wi-Fi Protected Access|WPA]] encryption, and now uses a cheaper SoftMAC card instead of the BenQ device which embedded its own 802.11 protocol stack.{{cite news |title=New Nabaztag/tag |date=9 November 2006 |website=[[i4U]] |url=http://www.i4u.com/article7067.html}} ==Cessation of service== Mindscape, filing for bankruptcy, discontinued the Nabaztag/tag web service in late July 2011.{{cite web |url=http://blog.karotz.com/?page_id=4592&lang=en |title=NABAZTAG |website=Karotz |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120424010314/http://blog.karotz.com/?page_id=4592&lang=en |archivedate=24 April 2012}} Alternative servers are available, including: *[http://www.Nabaztaglives.com/ NabaztagLives.com] *[http://www.nabizdead.net/ NabIzDead] *[http://openjabnab.fr/ojn_admin/ OpenJabNab] *[http://sourceforge.net/projects/opennab/ OpenNab (written in PHP)] *[https://github.com/quimarche/trudy/ Trudy] *[http://Nabaztag.forumactif.fr/t13280-recapitulatifs-des-solutions-alternatives/ other services] It however should be noted that these services, and others not listed here, can't support the older Nabaztag. The older units can currently be connected to a user-driven restoration of the old domain; however, the user is currently unable to add new applications or customize the Nabaztag ''v1'' configuration. As for now (January 2012), the older units are provided with random utterances of French phrases and jokes (the ''Moods'' application), periodic choreographies of ear movements and lights (the ''Tai-Chi'' application) and a fixed sleep-awake cycle, as the older units used a proprietary audio format and were handled by the Violet/Mindscape server in a different way than the Nabaztag/tag.{{cite web |url=http://Nabaztag.forumactif.fr/t13785-v1-ressusciter-son-v1#352348 |title=Ressusciter son V1 |website=nabaztag.forumactif |date=20 December 2011 |language=French}} ==Karotz== Karotz is the third generation Nabaztag, and first to be released since the Mindscape purchase. Like its predecessors, Karotz connects to the Internet using Wi-Fi and has RFID reading capability. Additionally, it includes an integrated web cam, a USB port (which can be used for power as well as connectivity), and 256 MB of onboard storage. Karotz was released in April 2011 and is heavily integrated with Facebook and Twitter.{{cite web |url=http://blog.karotz.com/?p=1545&lang=en |title=Karotz points his ears straight up in March 2011! |website=Blog.karotz.com |date= |accessdate=11 May 2011}} In October 2011 Mindscape was taken over by Aldebaran Robotics quoting "Together we shall go on with this wonderful adventure". In October 2014 Aldebaran Robotics [http://www.karotz.com/support/faq?locale=en_US announce]"The end of Karotz's adventures" with "nearly 10 years after its first appearance, Karotz is facing a very strong technological competition: the connected devices are now 4G, mobile and evolutionary. Karotz and its users have not only helped establish connected devices; they have paved the way. New products make a stronger match to market needs, marking the end of Karotz's great story." "Karotz's servers and customer service will be stopped on February 18th, 2015" ==Karotz Private Servers== In 2016, two years after "The end of Karotz's adventures" a new English enabled API has been set up to bring Karotz out of retirement from a volunteer initiative called [http://www.freerabbits.nl Free Rabbits!] == Security == During [[DEF CON|DEF CON 21]], Daniel Crowley, Jenniver Savage and David Bryan pointed out several security vulnerabilities{{cite web |url=https://www.defcon.org/images/defcon-21/dc-21-presentations/Crowley-Panel/DEFCON-21-Crowley-Savage-Bryan-Home-Invasion-2.0.pdf |title=Home Invasion v2.0: Attacking Network-Controlled Embedded Devices |website=Def Con}} about the Karotz. Unsecured connections to the website's provider could allow a [[Hacker (computer security)|hacker]] to steal the users' [[Wifi]] passwords, take control of the Karotz, installing a [[malware]]{{cite web |url=https://www.trustwave.com/Resources/Security-Advisories/Advisories/TWSL2013-021/?fid=3871 |title=Security Advisory TWSL2013-021: Multiple Vulnerabilities in Karotz Smart Rabbit |website=Trustwave SpiderLabs |date=1 August 2013}} and even to corrupt the device without any knowledge of the end user. During the same talk, they also show how it was possible to spy around the Karotz due to the presence of the camera and the microphone embedded in the bunny. ==Awards== Violet was awarded honourable mentions, category ''Small companies'' of the [[Design Management Europe Award|DME Award]] 2007 for Nabaztag.{{cite web |url=http://www.designmanagementeurope.com/site/index.php?page=9 |title=Winners |publisher=Design Management Europe.com |date= |accessdate=11 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110404071229/http://www.designmanagementeurope.com/site/index.php?page=9 |archivedate=4 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Nabaztag/tag was awarded for [[Netxplorateur of the Year]] in 2008.{{cite web |url=http://2008.netexplorateur.org/Net100.php?lang=EN |title=NetExplorateur 2008 |website=NetExplorateur.org |date= |accessdate=11 May 2011}} Nabaz'mob was awarded by [[Prix Ars Electronica]] Digital Musics 2009 (Award of Distinction).{{cite web |url=http://www.aec.at/prix_history_en.php?year=2009 |title=Prix Ars Electronica |website=ARS Electronica |date= |accessdate=11 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101025084014/http://aec.at/prix_history_en.php?year=2009 |archivedate=25 October 2010 |df=dmy-all }} ==See also== *[[Internet of Things]] *[[Ubiquitous computing]] *[[Digital pet]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * {{Official website|http://www.Nabaztag.com}} * [http://www.nabazik.fr.cr/ Music&Radio on your Nabaztag]{{spaced ndash}}Musics/Radios on Nabaztag * [http://www.nabzone.com/?MaLangue=en The Nabzone]{{spaced ndash}}Widgets and customisations for the Nabaztag * [http://nabazmob.free.fr Nabaz'mob]{{spaced ndash}}Site about the "opera for 100 smart rabbits" event * [http://karotz.com karotz.com]{{spaced ndash}}Official site of Nabaztag successor [[Category:Virtual pets]]
